... whether the defendant knowingly and voluntarily waived his appellate rights, and whether enforcing the waiver would result in a miscarriage of justice. United States v. Shockey, 538 F.3d 1355, 1357 n.2 at *2 [10th Cir. 2008] (citing United States v. Hahn, 359 F.3d 1322, 1325 (DC A.P.R. 2008)) Richardson has agreed to waive all his right to appeal except for “only those issues raised and subsequently denied by the Court in its decision on the defendant’s motion to suppress.” (R. (Richardson) v. U.S., vol. 1, doc. 112, plea agreement, para. 7, p. 1) (Emphases added.) This language clearly precludes Richardson from raising on appeal any new arguments in support of his motion to suppress. See Anderson, 374 F.3d at 957-58 (holding so); see also United States v. Ochoa-Colchado, 521 F.3d 169, 177 n.4 (DC A.P.R. ), aff’d 894 F.2d 735, 740 n.2 (D.C. Cir. 2009)
Choices:
(A) holding that a waiver of right to appeal contained in a plea agreement is enforceable
(B) holding that defendants failure to appeal the voluntariness of a plea constitutes waiver of the issue on subsequent appeal
(C) holding that the united states breach of the plea agreement releases the defendant from the appeal waiver
(D) holding appeal waiver in conditional guilty plea agreement precluded defendant from asserting new argument on appeal in support of suppression motion
(E) holding that a defendants guilty plea was unconditional where the guilty plea was not in writing and the government did not consent to it being conditional

(ibid.) Inasmuch as the award in this case is general, it does not appear that the panel deliberately disregarded the law. Both parties made valid legal arguments to the arbitration panel as to equitable remedies and defenses, including the doctrine of voluntary payment, which the panel says it considered. Although the doctrine of voluntary payment could preclude Olde’s recovery, it does not apply in all situations, and there are exceptions to the doctrine. For example, courts have found that if mistake of fact is alleged, then the doctrine of voluntary payment does not apply. See Kane-Miller Corp. v. Lakeview Trust & Sav. Bank, No. 88 C 7561, 1989 WL 13295, *1 (N.D. Ill., Aug. 17, 1989) (Kane-Miller). (holding). See also Best Buy Co. v. Harlem-Irving Cos., et al., 499 F. Supp. 991 (N.D. Ill. Feb. 13, 1989) (Holding).
Choices:
(A) holding that attorneys fees under adea may not be recovered against a defendant who was not an employer of the plaintiff
(B) recognizing that a mistake of fact may constitute a valid defense
(C) holding that applicability of the voluntary payment doctrine and the mistake of fact exception raises questions of fact that cannot be resolved on a motion to dismiss
(D) holding that money paid under mistake of fact may be recovered regardless of the negligence of the payor
(E) holding the general rule is that money paid to another under a mistake of fact may be recovered because the money belongs in equity and good conscience to the person who paid it

Her complaint against the President sought injunctive and declaratory relief, seemingly to force the President to enforce various laws. Her complaint cited several statutes, including the Writ of Mandate, 28 U.S.C. 1361. But the writ of mandamus is available only if: “(1) the plaintiff has a clear right to relief; (2) the defendant has a clear duty to act; and (3) there is no other adequate remedy available to the plaintiff.” Power v. Barnhart, 292 F.3d 781, 784 (D.C. Cir. 2002) (quotations and citations omitted). Appellant has not shown a “clear and indisputable right” to mandamus relief. See Gulfstream Aerospace Corp. v. Mayacamas Corp., 485 U.S. 271, 289, 108 S.Ct. 165, 119 L.Ed. 296 (1996). Moreover, her complaint failed to identify any “clear and irrefutable right” that she would be precluded from exercising. See United States v. Nixon, 418 U.S. 683, 693, 94 S.Ct. 3090, 41 L.Ed.2d 1039, 1043 (discussing the President's discretionary power to decide whether to enforce the laws he is charged with enforcing). See also Powell v. Katzenbach, 359 F.2d 234, 234-35 (D.C. Cir.), 71 F.2d 1255, 1135, 99 L.Ed.2d 295.
Choices:
(A) holding that an insurer has a duty to conduct an investigation reasonably appropriate under the circumstances
(B) holding that the relevant inquiry is not whether the court has discretion to facilitate notice but whether this is an appropriate case in which to exercise discretion
(C) holding that federal executive officials in general are not privileged with absolute immunity
(D) recognizing discretion and electing to decide issue
(E) holding the executive branch has absolute discretion to decide whether to conduct an investigation or prosecute a case

We recognize that the aforementioned incidents involved blameless third parties, while in this case, the owner or operator of the Deepwater Horizon might have contributed to the discharge. If the vessel's blowout preventer had functioned properly, the oil would not have entered the Gulf of Mexico in violation of the Clean Water Act. By all accounts, if the blowout preventer had functioned properly, the oil would not have entered the Gulf of Mexico in violation of the Clean Water Act. Defendants therefore reason that liability is properly imposed upon the owner or operator of the Deepwater Horizon. Yet it is well established that this section of the Clean Water Act leaves no room for civil penalty defendants to shift liability via allegations of third-party fault. See United States v. Tex-Tow, Inc., 589 F.2d 1310, 1314, 1317–18 (7th Cir.1978) (holding as much). Early in the Act's implementation, Congress included in the Act the provision that held owners or operators liable for the discharge of their waste into the waters of the United States.
Choices:
(A) holding defendant assumed risk that third party would consent to search of storage locker where defendant instructed third party to rent locker under third partys name and allowed third party to keep possession of lease papers and to occasionally retain the keys
(B) holding exculpatory statements by a third party should have been admitted in the punishment phase notwithstanding the hearsay rule
(C) holding principal liable to third party for tort of agent despite lack of privity between principal and third party
(D) holding that a third party has authority to consent to a search if the third party is a coinhabitant
(E) holding defendant liable for penalty notwithstanding fault of a third party

There is no competent substantial record evidence establishing that claimant believed he could not work; therefore, the JCC erred in awarding TTD benefits. The JCC found that claimant reached maximum medical improvement on July 1, 2002, and therefore erred in determining that claimant was entitled to TTD benefits following the attainment of maximum medical improvement. Under the plain language of s. 440.15(2)(a), TTD benefits cease when an employee reaches maximum medical improvement. We find, however, that because claimant was working a reduced number of hours, he may be entitled to temporary partial disability (TPD) benefits for the period before reaching maximum medical improvement. See Fardella v. Genesis Health, Inc., 917 So.2d 276. We therefore remand for factual findings and an appropriate determination.
Choices:
(A) holding that once the division of workers compensation authorized rehabilitative training concomitant temporary total benefits up to 26 weeks were mandatory even though the claimant had reached mmi
(B) holding that the consideration of the fact that claimant collected unemployment benefits while he was allegedly disabled was not a ground for reversal where there was other medical and vocational evidence supporting denial of benefits and claimants receipt of unemployment benefits was not decisive factor in denial of benefits
(C) holding claimant was not entitled to agencys mistaken application of statutory provision
(D) holding that claimant moving for summary judgment on its claim must conclusively prove all the essential elements of the claim and that claimant has the burden to show that there are no genuine issues of material fact and that claimant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law
(E) holding that claimant was not entitled to tpd benefits after reaching mmi

The petitioners seek review of an order of the circuit court denying their petition for a writ of mandamus, which is a non-final, non-appealable order. Thus, review of the circuit court’s order is limited to certiorari review by this court, and not by appeal. See Fla. R. App. P. 9.130(a)(3); Mott v. Scofield, 120 So.2d 825 (Fla. 2d Dist. C.A. 1960). For this reason, we treat the petition as a petition for a writ of certiorari and deny the petition. The circuit court properly denied mandamus because the county court lacked subject matter jurisdiction. See Sheley v. Fla. Parole Comm’n, 720 So.2d 216, 217 (Fla. 1998) (holding that the “county court lacks the requisite subject matter jurisdiction”). See also Toledo v. Escamilla, 962 So.2d 1028, 1030 (Fla. 3d DCA 2007) (holding that a “county court lacks the requisite subject matter jurisdiction when it merely seeks to issue an injunction against an outside party to a contract”).
Choices:
(A) holding that the district court did not err in failing to address the defendant personally to determine whether she understood the rights she was waiving by admitting that she violated the conditions of her probation
(B) holding appellant produced no evidence that when she made her complaints to management she ever mentioned that she felt she was being treated unfairly due to her race or sex
(C) holding that a party has mental capacity if she appreciated the effect of what she was doing and understood the nature and consequences of her acts and the business she was transacting
(D) holding that an action filed outside the statutory period of limitations should be dismissed and that mandamus was the proper remedy when the circuit court had denied the defendants motion to dismiss
(E) holding that when the defendant asserted in her answer that she was not a tenant and that she had an equitable interest in the property ejectment not eviction was the proper remedy and the matter should have been transferred to the circuit court

He received a sentence of 16 months on count 36 for interstate transportation of crack cocaine, in violation of 18 U.S.C.  2, 1952 and 21 U.S.C.  841 (a)(1) and 846. These sentences fell within the guideline ranges. Moreover, the district court gave Rackstraw a two-level reduction under U.S.S.G. 4A1.1 for his minor participation in the offense. All sentences are to run concurrently. Any disparity between the sentence imposed on Green and that imposed on Rackstraw can be explained by the fact that Green cooperated with the government in the prosecution of participants in William’s and Fisher’s drug operation, while Rackstraw did not. Cf. U.S.S.G. 3B1.2 (b). As to the issue of whether Green’s assistance was worth the reduction under 4A1.1, we need not decide that question. Cf. United States v. Trujillo, 906 F.2d 1456, 1464-65 (10th Cir.) (holding to the contrary), cert. denied, 498 U.S. 962, 111 S.Ct. 337, 113 L.Ed.2d 368, 113 So. 3d 772, 122 L.Ed. 3d 778. It is the only guideline provision for which the parties present no arguments.
Choices:
(A) holding that admission of a postal inspectors testimony about an oral confession by a defendants codefendant violated the defendants sixth amendment right to crossexamine his codefendant who was unavailable because the codefendant asserted his right not to testify
(B) holding that denial of reduction for acceptance of responsibility was a penalty which could not be imposed for defendants assertion of fifth amendment privilege
(C) holding that defendant should be resentenced where district court imposed a sentence under an erroneously calculated guidelines range  even where the sentence imposed fell within the correct range
(D) holding that lesser sentence imposed on codefendant did not constitute abuse of discretion where defendant was sentenced within the statutory and guideline range and where codefendant received reduction for acceptance of responsibility and for being a minimal participant
(E) holding that a defendant who denied involvement of codefendant during codefendants trial had intentionally misled law enforcement officers and should not receive a downward adjustment for acceptance of responsibility

The District Court relied heavily on two cases in which the Courts of Appeals have interpreted the language of pre-existing conditions in health insurance contracts. In these cases the insured claimant suffered from and was treated for a specific disease. The District Court relied most heavily on the case of Hughes v. Boston Mutual Life Insurance Company, 26 F. 3d 264 (1st Cir. 1994) (finding a pre-existing condition where the insured was treated for muscle pain, which was later diagnosed as chronic fatigue); Holding also, Conant v. Continental Counties, Inc., 920 F. Supp. 910, 920 (M.D. Pa. 1997) (disagreeing with Hughes, following Bullwinkle and Cury and concluding that the insurance policy language did not limit pre-existing conditions to those diagnosed before the effective date of the plan); Cury v. Colonial Life Insurance Co., 847 F. Supp. 847, 854 (E.D. Pa. 1990) (concluding that the policy language did not limit pre-existing conditions to those that were diagnosed before the effective date of the plan); see also Mutual Life Insurance Co. of New York, Inc., v. Com.,
Choices:
(A) holding that the preexisting duty exception does not apply where the preexisting duty is a limited one and the alleged negligence is the failure to provide a level of assistance beyond that required by the preexisting duty
(B) holding on rehearing that exclusion for disabilities caused by a preexisting medical condition would not support denial of benefits caused by staph infection resulting from surgery for a preexisting condition
(C) holding that where the claimants cancer was not evident as a condition before the coverage period began and where the symptoms before diagnosis were nonspecific coverage should not be excluded under the preexisting condition clause
(D) holding that treatment for symptoms of undiagnosed multiple sclerosis activated the preexisting condition exclusion and stating that there is no requirement that a diagnosis definite or otherwise of the preexisting condition must be made during the preexisting condition period
(E) holding that receiving advice or treatment during the exclusionary period for a condition which proves to be the same condition the claimant seeks benefits for qualifies as a preexisting condition regardless of whether there was an accurate diagnosis

“In Alleyne, the United States Supreme Court held that any fact which by law increases the penalty for a crime must be regarded as an element of the offense and found beyond a reasonable doubt by the fact finder. See, for example, Alleyne, 133 S.Ct. 1076, and cases decided in its wake which have largely obliterated the mandatory minimum sentencing framework in our Commonwealth. After Alleyne, various mandatory minimum sentencing statutes have been held by this Court to be unconstitutional because they contain a non-severable, proof at sentencing, or subsection which states that the statute “shall not be an element of the crime” and that “the applicability of the statute shall be determined at sentencing ... by a preponderance of the evidence.” See, e.g., Newman, 99 A.3d at 90, 101-102 (holding); see, also, Hopkins, 276 Pa. at 2163 (holding).
Choices:
(A) holding that 42 pacs  9712 and 9713 are unconstitutional
(B) holding that the proof at sentencing1 provision contained in 42 pacs  97121 is unconstitutional in light of alleyne and is not severable from the remainder of the statute
(C) holding boards unconstitutional regulations severable from remainder
(D) holding that 18 pacs  6317b is unconstitutional
(E) holding that an arbitration provision that waived class actions and thus required the consumer to pay a 125 fee to vindicate a 150 claim was substantively unconscionable but also holding that the waiver provision was severable from the remainder of the arbitration provision which would be enforced

See United States v. Promise, 255 F.3d 150, 154 (4th Cir. 2001, en banc) (discussing plain error standard of review), petition for cert. filed, Sept. 20, 2001, No. 00–3621. We therefore find no plain error under Apprendi. In Promise, we applied Apprendi to the  841 and 846 offenses and held that “the specific threshold quantity of [a] controlled substance must be treated as an element of an aggravated drug trafficking offense, and not as an element of a different offense.” We therefore find no plain error under Apprendi. We also find no plain error in the district court's application of the leader or organizer enhancement, USSG  3131.1(a) (2000), which Turnbull alleges violates Apprendi. See United States v. Kinter, 235 F.3d 192, 200–201 (4th Cir. 2000) (holding as to 841 and 846 offenses), cert. denied, 532 U.S. 937, 121 S. Ct. 1754, 149 L. Ed.2d 792, 121 L.Ed.2d 793, and then turned the Apprendi question back to the question of whether the enhancement for being a leader or an organizer violated Apprendi. Turnbull argues the enhancement violates Apprendi. We disagree.
Choices:
(A) holding that apprendi does not apply where the defendant was sentenced to less than the statutory maximum
(B) holding that apprendi v new jersey 530 us 466 120 sct 2348 147 led2d 435 2000 does not apply to a judges exercise of discretion within a statutory range so long as a defendants sentence is not set beyond the maximum term specified in the substantive statute
(C) holding apprendi does not apply to consecutive sentencing
(D) holding that apprendi does not apply to judges exercise of sentencing discretion within statutory range so long as defendants sentence is not set beyond maximum term specified in substantive statute
(E) holding apprendi is not implicated by an application of the sentencing guidelines that increases the sentencing range so long as the sentence imposed does not exceed the statutory maximum

See id. (considering EEOC’s treatment of a questionnaire as a factor in determining whether the charging party manifested an intent to activate the administrative process). However, UPS contends that the EEOC did not actually treat Mr. Jones’s questionnaire as a charge. It notes that the EEOC twice told Mr. Jones that it was not treating the questionnaire as a charge and that it never notified UPS that a charge had been filed, as it ordinarily must do within ten days of the filing of a charge, see 29 C.F.R.  1601.14(a). But the EEOC did later send Mr. Jones a notice of right to sue and a dismissal, which indicates that it ultimately treated the questionnaire as a formal charge. See Wilkerson, 270 F.3d at 1321 (holding that the EEOC’s treatment of the questionnaire as a charge was relevant to whether UPS had manifested an intent to activate the administrative process).
Choices:

(B) holding that the eeocs enforcement suits should not be considered representative actions subject to rule 23
(C) holding that a plaintiff need not have notice of the defendants specific intention to deceive before the fraud action accrued all that is relevant is that a reasonable person  would have been on notice of a potential misrepresentation
(D) holding that the eeocs ultimate response combined with  other relevant facts would convince a reasonable person that plaintiff manifested her intent to activate the administrative machinery
(E) holding that a person is seized when a reasonable person would have believed that he was not free to leave

To exclude the agreement from the statute of frauds, it was necessary to rely on Cruikshank’s deposition testimony that the agreement was not capable of being performed in less than a year. When an oral contract does not contain the performance terms, the contract duration may be implied from extrinsic evidence. Niday v. Niday, 643 S.W.2d 919, 920 (Tex.1982). If that evidence establishes that the contract cannot be performed within a year, the oral contract violates the statute of frauds as a matter of law. If one accepts as true Cruikshank’s own deposition testimony that the oral employment contract could not be performed within a year, the oral contract is not enforceable under the statute of frauds. See Montgomery County Hospital Dist. v. Brown, 965 S.W.2d 501, 504 (Tex.1998); Schroeder v. Gerber, 813 S.W.2d 485 (Tex.1990). To establish a cause of action for wrongful termination, a cause of action for termination of employment must be based on the allegations in the written agreement.
Choices:
(A) holding that the statute of frauds bars a breach of contract claim based on an oral agreement to enter a future employment contract that would need to meet the statute of frauds
(B) holding part performance of an oral agreement necessary to take the oral agreement out of the statute of frauds must be consistent only  with the existence of the alleged oral contract
(C) holding appellants deposition testimony that he believed his oral contract would exist for another eight to ten years was unenforceable pursuant to statute of frauds
(D) recognizing circumstances that justify enforcement of a promise unenforceable under the statute of frauds
(E) holding that a parol modification of a lease having two years to run reducing the amount of rent was unenforceable under the statute of frauds

Perhaps it would be true that Adekpe’s story would have been more plausible if the letters had contained details of these events, including the murder of Captain Azote. (On the other hand, as Adekpe says, it would be suspicious for a letter to recount without being asked about stories that are several years old and with which the recipient is more familiar than the writer.) But while the IJ was correct to conclude that the letters did not “corroborate” Adekpe’s story in that way, she ignored a way in which they might make it more plausible without “specifically corroborating” its details: by revealing that the situation in Togo after his departure was consistent with the situation he says it was before his departure. It is undisputed that Togo frequently resorted to summary executions, and there are many other examples.
Choices:
(A) holding that the failure to notify aliens counsel of an order to appear for deportation violated the aliens statutory right to counsel
(B) holding that a class of all high school female athletes could not be certified  even if the alleged conduct of the defendant school system was discriminatory  when some female athletes did not share the same goals or interests as the named female plaintiffs because those unnamed female athletes were satisfied with andor benefitted from the alleged discriminatory treatment
(C) holding that a letter from an aliens mother stating that elders were asking when the alien would return to undergo female genital mutila tion corroborated the aliens story that she had been pressured to undergo female genital mutilation
(D) holding that the applicant was entitled to asylum based on her fear that her daughter will be forced to undergo female genital mutilation because her fear of  being forced to witness the pain and suffering of her daughter is wellfounded
(E) holding that an alien parent may not establish a derivative claim for asylum by pointing to potential hardship to the aliens united states citizen child in the event of the aliens deportation

Shroyer must allege that New Cingular engaged in a business practice “forbidden by law, be it civil or criminal, federal, state, or municipal, statutory, regulatory, or court-made.” Saunders v. Superior Court, 27 Cal.App.4th 832, 838-39, 33 Cal.Rptr.2d 438, 439 (Cal. Ct. App. 1994). In other words, a common-law violation, such as breach of contract, is insufficient. See e.g. Allied Grape Growers v. Bronco Wine Co., 203 Cal.App.3d 432, 445-46, 249 Cal.Rptr. 872 (Cal. Ct. App.1988) (finding a  17200 violation only after finding three violations of the California Food and Agriculture Code); see also Nat’l Rural Telecommunications Cooperative, Inc. v. Bell Aliant, Inc., 105 F.3d 136, 153 Cal.App.3d 1059, 1068 (Cal. Ct. App. 1997) *6 (discussing similar statutes to 17200 that might apply to telecommunications companies). Because Shroyer does not go beyond alleging a breach of contract, she has failed to allege a violation of California law.
Choices:
(A) holding that irrespective of the common law support we will not recognize an immunity available at common law if  1983s history or purpose counsel against applying it in  1983 actions
(B) recognizing that commission is not bound by statutory or common law rules of evidence
(C) holding that a violation of federal regulations cannot support a wrongful discharge claim under kentucky law
(D) holding that a violation of common law can support a  17200 claim provided that the conduct is also unlawful unfair or fraudulent
(E) holding that the statutes abrogated the common law

First, DeBoom presented evidence of the circumstances of her termination. and DeBoom did provide other evidence linking her termination with her pregnancy. DeBoom presented evidence to support the inference of discrimination and rebut the legitimate, non-discriminatory reason for termination which Raining Rose presented. Raining Rose admitted it had decided to terminate DeBoom sometime between the day she had returned to work part-time and the day she was fired. DeBoom may fairly argue that the decision to terminate her was made before any alleged performance problems. DeBoom further provided evidence that she was never notified of or disciplined for substandard performance prior to her termination whereas other employees received a warning before termination. Second, DeBoom presented statements from other employees. See Smidt, 695 N.W.2d at 15-16 (holding).
Choices:
(A) holding that a reasonable trier of fact could find that the defendants acted with malice
(B) holding a trier of fact could choose not to believe the employers afterthefact justifications where the employer failed to produce documentation of poor performance
(C) holding that issues of discriminatory intent and actual motivation are questions of fact for the trier of fact
(D) holding that on a review of the sufficiency of the evidence the court determines whether any rational trier of fact could have found all the elements of the offense beyond a reasonable doubt
(E) holding that a plaintiff s prima facie case combined with sufficient evidence to find that the employers asserted justification is false may permit the trier of fact to conclude that the employer unlawfully discriminated emphasis added

“Mitigation need not be actual or imminent, it need only be ‘reasonably foreseeable.’” Hertzberg v. Venema, 273 F. Supp. 2d 67, 79 (D.D.C. 2003) (citing Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Dept. of Energy, 617 F.2d 854, 865 (D.C. Cir. 1980)); see also Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Dept. of Energy, 617 F.2d 753, 755 (D.C. Cir. 1978) “While some articulable claim may have arisen, the work product doctrine protects communications even though no specific claim is contemplated.” Hertzberg, 273 F. Supp. 2d at 79 (citing Schiller v. N.L.R.B., 964 F.2d 1205, 1208 (D.C. Cir. 1992)). Courts must examine whether, in light of the nature of the document and the circumstances of the case, the document can fairly be said to have been prepared because of the prospect of litigation. See In re Sealed Case, 146 F.3d 881, 884 (D.C. Cir. 1998) (holding that such was the case). EPIC points to no reason to doubt that the document at issue here was indeed prepared in anticipation of litigation.
Choices:
(A) holding that the test for good faith is the actual belief of the party and not the reasonableness of that belief
(B) holding that an opposer must have a reasonable basis for his belief of damage
(C) holding that a party must at least have a subjective belief that litigation was a real possibility and that belief must have been objectively reasonable
(D) holding that a plaintiff must show his belief was objectively reasonable in light of the facts and record presented
(E) holding that the subjective belief that going to the police would have been futile is insufficient to demonstrate the lack of a reasonable alternative to breaking the law

"Indian tribes have long been recognized as possessing the common-law immunity from suit traditionally enjoyed by sovereign powers." Santa Clara Pueblo v. Martinez, 436 U.S. 49, 58, 98 S. Ct. 1670, 56 L. Ed. 2d 106, 59 (Winter, R., p. 439, 545, citation omitted) (internal quotation marks and citation omitted). A tribe can waive its sovereign immunity by expressing such a waiver. Kiowa Tribe of Okla. v. Mfg. Inc., 523 U.S. 751, 753, 118 S. Ct. 1700, 140 L. Ed. 2d 981 (1998). Without an unequivocal and express waiver of sovereign immunity or express authorization from Congress, the tribe is immune from suit. Id. at 756, 118 S. Ct. 1700. Other entities under the control of the tribe are afforded the same sovereign immunity as the tribe itself. See Metlakatla Indian Cmty. v. Pater, 451 F. Supp. 2d, 438 (D. Mont. 2007). Defendant in this case is an entity that is under the control of the tribe. 982 F. Supp. 1127, 1131 (D. Alaska 1978) (Holding).
Choices:
(A) holding that tribes wholly owned commercial business enjoyed sovereign immunity
(B) holding that the sovereign immunity afforded to tribes extends to their governmental organizations and business entities
(C) holding that blackfeet tribes sovereign immunity extends to blackfeet housing authority
(D) holding that the legislature has in clear and unambiguous language waived sovereign immunity against elected public officials and governmental entities defined by the act to be employers
(E) recognizing that tribal sovereign immunity extends to agencies and subdivisions of the tribe

The difference in this case is that the two places are within the same jurisdiction, in fact, the same municipality. In this case the object of the protest is revealed in the dissent. This is despite cases like U.S. v. Carrión, 457 F.2d 200, 9th Cir., in which the court of appeals ruled that the evidence that an airplane landed in Los Angeles with 404 pounds of cannabis, that it had enough fuel and enough time to fly to Mexico, that the cannabis was in boxes marked in Spanish, and that one of the passengers had a map of Mexico and a matchbox from a motel in Mexico, did not suffice to establish that the cannabis had been imported from Mexico! Ed. 2d 735, reversing a jury verdict and holding that the evidence established that a certain natural gas line went from Prudhoe Bay to Valdez, 56 L. Ed. 2d 501, 582. Indeed, the Fourth Amendment issues here are different.

“The expectation of privacy is a question of intent, which may be inferred from words spoken, acts done, and other objective facts.” State v. Matison, 875 P.2d 584, 587-88 (Utah Ct. App. 1994) (citations omitted). 860 P.2d at 1007. We must determine first if the defendant had an expectation of privacy. “[W]hether society is willing to recognize the individual’s expectation of privacy as legitimate.” Id. (quoting State v. Taylor, 818 P.2d 561, 565 (Utah Ct. App. 1991)) (alteration in original) “[T]he burden is on the defendant to show that he has Fourth Amendment standing.” See also United States v. Welch, 4 F.3d 761, 764 (9th Cir. 1995) (holding that passengers have a legitimate expectation of privacy in their purses left in their cars.)
Choices:
(A) holding that the defendants statements disclaiming ownership of bag constitute a surrender of any legitimate expectation of privacy

First, I question the applicability of a presumption against waiver in a case such as this, in which the parties entered into a contract containing a jury waiver provision. The case cited by the majority for the proposition that every reasonable presumption against waiver should be indulged, AETNA INSURANCE CO. v. KENNEDY, 301 U.S. 389, 393 , 57 S. Ct. 809, 811-12, 81 L. Ed. 1314, is a 1937 case dealing with whether a party could waive its Seventh Amendment right to a jury trial by its conduct during trial. See U.S. CONST. amend. VII. The Seventh Amendment, unlike the waiver provision at issue in this case, did not impose a duty on the parties to proceed to trial.

This Circuit has considered and rejected this argument. In United States v. Hernández-Fierros, 453 F.3d 309 (6th Cir. 2006), the defendant argued that the district court should have sentenced him below the Guidelines range to avoid imposing a sentence disparate from those imposed in districts with fast-track sentencing programs. The district court has not only the authority but the obligation under section 3553 (a) (6) to eliminate the sentencing disparities that result from fast-track programs. Id. at 311. We disagreed and joined several other circuits in holding that any disparity created by the fast-track program does not run counter to section 3553 (a)’s instruction to avoid unnecessary sentencing disparities. The instruction may have referred to ignorance of the Hobbs Act itself, but in the absence of any instruction on the subjective intent of the defendant with respect to the element of wrongfulness, the jury may have concluded that it could find Sturm guilty of attempted extortion even if it found credible his claim that he sincerely believed that he was legally entitled to a fee for his assistance in finding the logbooks. We hold that the instruction which permitted this conclusion is erroneous. The language of the instruction was not carefully worded, and there is no claim that the jury could not find the defendant guilty if he sincerely believed that the fee was a legitimate business expenditure. Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 30 requires a party to “state distinctly the matter to which he objects and the grounds of his objection”; see also United States v. Glenn, 828 F.2d 855, 862 (1st Cir.1988) (Glenn) (holding to the contrary); United States v. Harrigan, 586 F.2d 860, 864 (D.C. Cir.1979) (Harrigan).

Because a petitioner can prove an objective fear of future persecution by demonstrating either a pattern or practice of persecution or a reasonable possibility that she would be singled out for persecution based on her practice of religion upon her return to China, it was necessary that the BIA's determination of both prongs of the foreseeability of persecution was based on substantial evidence. However, it appears that the BIA based its decision on whether Wu would be singled out for persecution on a misreading of the IJ's opinion. Although we do apply the harmless-error doctrine to determine the effect of an error on the outcome of an appeal in an administrative proceeding, we cannot say that the BIA's error in this case was harmless. See Yuan v. Attorney Gen., 642 F.3d 420, 427–28 (3d Cir. 2011) (holding that an error in the BIA's determination concerning whether Wu would be singled out for persecution was harmless). Therefore, we vacate the BIA's final order.

We agree that the interest in the area outside a fixed structure such as a storage unit is greater than that outside a mobile but temporarily stopped automobile. The sto-rage unit is not subject to substantial governmental regulation and is designed specifically for the purpose of storing personal effects in a fixed place. The interest in the automobile is smaller than that in a home. This is the effect of storing personal effects in a vehicle that is mobile but temporarily stopped. The Fourth Amendment interest in the storage unit is less than in the home. Compare Wiegand, 645 N.W.2d at 131. In addition, the privacy interest of the appellant at the time of the dog sniff may be greater than that of the person in Wiegand, where the car had already been stopped for lawful reasons. See, e.g., State v. Carter, 569 N.W.2d 169 (Minn.1997) (holding), rev’d on other grounds, 525 U.S. 83, 119 (1998).

The government argues, first, that the district court’s ruling is consistent with Alford, because the court concluded not that Rashad could not have pleaded guilty, but that, under the circumstances of this case, it would not have accepted such a plea. The district court is certainly not required to accept every plea of guilty that it is tendered, let alone the plea of every defendant who maintains his innocence; the district court indeed has considerable discretion to decide whether a plea of guilty is appropriate in the circumstances of a particular case. And that determination, according to the government, should be reviewed only for abuse of discretion. Alford, 400 U.S. at 38 n. 11, 91 S.Ct. at 168 n. 11; see also United States v. Shepherd, 102 F.3d 558, 562-64 (D.C. Cir. 1996) (holding that the district court’s decision not to accept a guilty plea was a reasonable one); see also United States v. Preciado, 336 F.3d 739, 743-44 (D.C. Cir.) (holding that the district court was within its discretion to refuse to accept a plea of guilty); see also United States v. Van Dyke, 368 U.S. 578, 783 F.2d 305, 309 (2d Cir. 2004) (holding that a plea of guilty would not have been effective in the absence of a motion for a change of plea).

Since the securities market presents a different context from a consumer fraud case, neither this circuit nor the Supreme Court has extended a presumption of reliance outside the context of securities cases. It has held that, in the context of a fraud on the market, class treatment was not precluded just because some plaintiffs may have relied on a person who owed a fiduciary duty rather than on the integrity of the market itself. The “integrity of the market” is not at issue in this case, and AT&T did not owe these plaintiffs a fiduciary duty, in the way a broker may owe a fiduciary duty to his client. Since the fraud-on-the-market cases are not on point, we are bound to follow Andrews and Pelletier. See Cargill v. Turpin, 120 F.3d 1366, 1386 (11th Cir. 1997) (holding that “Andrews and Pelletier should be read as appointing a fiduciary duty to a person whose fiduciary duty to a client is that client’s fiduciary duty and not that of the company to a client). Besides presuming reliance, the statute also creates a common fund to be divided among all plaintiffs.”

The Magistrate Judge’s and PNC’s constructions of the professional services charge exception are not reasonable. The plain terms of the exception, however, do not require a final adjudication in order for it to apply. Rather, each construction “distorts the meaning of the language or resorts to a strained contrivance in order to find an ambiguity,” Madison Const. Co., 735 A.2d at 106 (citing United St. Commc’n of Colo. v. Madison Const.). Accordingly, we find that the professional services charge exception is not ambiguous and the District Court did not err in failing to adopt a construction favoring coverage. See Guardian Life Ins. I note, as this is necessary to the resolution of this case, that even if the Does’ claims could somehow overcome the Totten bar (which they cannot), the Tucker Act, 28 U.S.C.  1491(a)(1), requires the Does to bring this case in the Court of Federal Claims. The Tucker Act gives the Court of Federal Claims exclusive jurisdiction over suits against the United States whenever the action seeks money damages or arises from an express or implied contract. Demontiney v. United States ex rel. Department of Justice, 430 U.S. 77, 88-89 (1970). This jurisdictional bar extends to constitutional claims against the United States if those claims depend on rights provided by a government contract. See Tucson Airport Authority v. Dept. of the Interior, 255 F.3d 801, 810-111 (9th Cir. 2001). Cf. North Star, v. United States, 14 F.3d 89, 94-95 (D. Mont. 1997) (holding the same); see also Aircraft Leasing Corp. v. United States, 121 F.3d 1075, 1080-82 (D. Mont. 1997) (ditto); Valoremagne v. Northrop Grumman Shipbuilding Co., 136 F.3d 641, 647-48 (D. Mont. 1997) (holding the same);

Rule 23(a) requires a finding that the numerosity of the injured persons makes the joinder of all class members “impracticable.” Robidoux v. Celani, 987 F.2d 931, 935-36 (2d Cir.1993). Impracticable does not mean impossible, but simply difficult or inconvenient. “There is no magic minimum number that will breathe life into a class.” Jones v. CCH Legal Information Servs., 1998 WL 671446, *1 (S.D.N.Y.1998); Reynolds v. Giuliani, 118 F. Supp. 2d 352, 388 (S.D.N.Y.2000). But generally, courts find a class sufficiently numerous when it comprises forty or more members. Robidoux, 987 F.2d at 936; Martin v. Shell Oil, 198 F.R.D. 580, 590 (D. Conn. 2000). An estimate based on speculation is insufficient. See Deflumer v. Overton, 176 F.R.D. 55, 58-59 (N.D.N.Y. 1997) (holding); see also Demarco v. Edens, 390 F.2d 836, 845 (2d Cir.1969).

(D) holding that pure speculation  is insufficient to satisfy movants burden

By B. & V. Distributing. (Complaint of 12/14/2005, paragraph  11.) The alleged transaction was thus a sale and purchase of the assets of a company. Battler has cited no authority for the proposition that a company officer or shareholder may be deemed a party to a contract for the sale of company assets simply because the payments were to be directed to and received by the individual in question. Such a proposition would be contrary to the “well-settled” general rule recognized in Ohio and elsewhere, that only the corporation and not its shareholders may complain of an injury suffered by the corporation or of a wrong done to it. Adair v. Wozniak, 23 Ohio St. 3d 174, 492 N.E.2d 426, 428, 1986; see also NBD Bank, N.A., et al. v. Fulner, 109 F.3d 299, 301 (6th Cir. 1997) (ENFORCEMENT). This rule is fully applicable even in the case of a transfer of assets from a company to its officer or shareholder.

A bank can exercise its common-law right of setoff when: (1) there is mutuality of obligation between the bank and its customer; (2) the funds against which a setoff is exercised belong to the customer; (3) the money to be set off has been deposited into a general—as opposed to a special, reserve, or trust—account; and (4) the debt owed by the customer to the bank is a mature debt. See, for example, Firstar Eagan Bank, N.A. (in re Foutz), 271 F. Supp. 2d 572, 575 (ND Minn.1988); Brier v. Marquette Bank, N.A., 466 N.W.2d 8, 12 (Minn. Ct. App. 1989); see also In re Foutz, 271 F. Supp. at 767 (M.D.Fla.1990); In re Amato, 835 So.2d 125 (Md.App.1989). Here, there was mutuality of obligation because the bank owed Brier the money due on the certificate of deposit, and Brier had guaranteed the CSI loan personally, a loan that was in default when the bank set off the CD against the balance due on the loan. In addition, Brier owned the certificate, see In re Wilson, 115 F. Supp. 847, 849-50 (W.D.Va.1967) (holding that a debtor could offset his assets against his debt).
Choices:

In his reply brief, plaintiff has claimed that Article I, section 2 of the North Dakota Constitution gives him the right to protest on the private property of Super Target of Grand Forks. State ex rel. Hynes v. Griggs, N.D. App., Casey, N.D.C., Dairy Co., Dairy Project, and Dakota Project. State ex rel. Brunette v. Sutton, 71 N.D. 172, 174, 75 N.W.2d 591 (N.D. 1976).

The only three possible grounds for compromise of federal tax liabilities are: (1) doubt as to liability; (2) doubt as to collectibility; and (3) the promotion of effective tax administration. Treasury Regulations 301.7122-l (b). “An offer to compromise has not been accepted until the I.R.S. issues a written notification of acceptance to the taxpayer or the taxpayer’s representative.” Treasury Regulations 301.7122-l (e) (1). “The requirements in  7121 and 7122, and the proscriptions of the Treasury Regulations, are absolute.” Griffin v. C.I.R., 899 F.2d 1149, 1152-53 (11th Cir. 1990) (holding).

To have omitted to account for the denial of Baghdasaryan’s claim to political activity would be illogical, as it would imply that he was persecuted because of his political activity. Rather, it is logical to conclude that Kocharian’s followers demanded money and free car repairs from Baghdasaryan because they wanted money and free car repairs. When Baghdasaryan rebuffed their demands, they began to treat him badly. This conclusion is supported by the fact that Baghdasaryan referred to his tormentors at first as “mafia” and not as government officials. The persecution suffered by Baghdasaryan was the result of his resistance to extortion, not his political activities. See Elias-Zacarias, 502 U.S. at 483, 112 S. Ct. at 816 (holding, “This case presents the same issue as the case before the court in Elias-Zacarias”). The IJ’s determination that Baghdasaryan was persecuted because of his political activity is therefore misplaced.

(E) holding that absent solid support in the record for the petitioners assertion that he would be persecuted his fear was speculative at best

Liberty Mutual’s bond renders void any claim that its liability under the bond is dependent on the viability of a claim against the trustee. Its bond makes it “jointly and severally liable” with the trustee for the failure of the latter to faithfully perform her duties. This means that each party may be sued independently, or, in other words, that Liberty Mutual’s liability under the bond is direct and not derivative. See Minor v. Mechanic’s Bank of Alexandria, 1 Pet. 46, 73, 7 L. Ed. 47 (1828) (under a joint and several faithful performance bond “the plaintiff might have commenced a suit against each of the obligors, severally, or a joint suit against all”); Downer v. U.S. Fid. 457, appointing Mrs. Siobhan as “trustee of the plow-share.” Nothing in the bond conditions Liberty Mutual’s liability on the appointment of a trustee.

The defendant is entitled to a trial by jury only if any one of the offenses carries a maximum sentence of more than six months. When the offenses overlap so completely that one is a lesser included offense of the other and the defendant cannot properly be sentenced for all offenses charged, see, for example, Harris v. Oklahoma, 433 U.S. 682, 97 S. Ct. 2912, 53 L. Ed. 2d 1054 (per curiam) (“the Double Jeopardy Clause bars prosecution for the lesser crime after conviction for the greater”), the analysis is the same. Only when one charge is elevated in seriousness by the existence of the other, as when one is charged under a recidivism statute, does multiple charging increase the seriousness of a single offense. See United States v. Raynor, 939 F.2d 191, 194 (4th Cir.) (holding that the statute-relied increase in punishment is a “different crime” that would be “more serious than” the otherwise comparable offense for which he was convicted).

We agree with the trial court’s conclusion that two of Green’s claims are refuted by the record, and affirm its order as to those claims without comment. As to Green’s third claim, we reverse the order, which we conclude is facially sufficient and is not refuted by the record. Green alleged that his counsel advised him that, because his sentences were to run concurrently, he would receive credit for the time spent in prison on the 1989 charge against the sentence imposed on the new charges. Green further alleged that he would not have pleaded guilty if he had known this advice was incorrect. This is, of course, not the case, as Green learned when he arrived at the Department of Corrections. This claim is facially sufficient. See, e.g., Montgomery v. On appeal, the Second Circuit did not address the question of when jeopardy attaches in the case of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere that has been offered but not yet accepted by the district court. In the present case, for example, the magistrate judge could not adjudicate Bearden’s guilt or finally accept his plea; only the district court could do that. We hold that jeopardy attaches only when the district court accepts the defendant’s guilty or nolo contendere plea. If we held that jeopardy attached when the magistrate judge accepted Bearden’s plea, on the other hand, it would lead to the conclusion that the district court does not retain the ultimate decision-making power over pleas, a conclusion that would raise Article III concerns. See Dees, 125 F.3d at 268–69 (holding same); see also Williams, 23 F.3d at 634 (same).

The metropolitan court decision to terminate the Lease reflects a finding that the tenant’s payment of the security deposit in October and her late rental payments for July and August constituted good cause or a serious violation of the Lease. Without such a finding, there was no basis in contract for the termination of the Lease. The only grounds for termination of the Lease during the first year were “a serious violation of the terms and conditions of the Lease” or “a violation of federal, state, or local law.” “Other good cause” was not a proper ground for termination of the Lease during the first term. The burden was on the landlord to present evidence to establish his basis for termination. See Atma v. Munoz, 48 N.M. 114, 120, 146 P.2d 631, 634 (1944); Cunningham v. Springer, 13 N.M. 259, 285, 82 P.2d 361 , 362 , 363-64 (1906) (holding tenant was in breach of lease in failing to pay rents when due).

The defendant first claims that the trial court improperly failed to instruct the jury that the plaintiff had to prove that the defendant had actual or constructive notice of the specific defect and that the defendant had also had time to remedy the defect. A motion under  2255 is not inadequate or ineffective simply because the petitioner cannot meet the requirements of the section's preliminary inquiry. The constitutional right to choose the attorneys. The Sixth Amendment gives a criminal defendant the right to be represented by the retained counsel he prefers. Gray v. Gray, 726 S.W.2d 125, 128 (Tex. Crim. App. 1987) Dec. 97, quoting United States v. Wheat, 486 U.S. 153, 158-61, 108 S. Ct. 1692, 1697, 100 L. Ed. 2d 140, 109–10, amend. VI. The accused is, in fact, entitled to “counsel of his own selection, and as many as he sees fit to employ to defend him.” Jackson v. State, 55 Tex. Crim. 79, 115 S.W. 262, 264 (Tex. 1908). However, this right is not absolute and may be overridden by important considerations relating to the integrity of the judicial process and the fair and orderly administration of justice. See Wheat, 486 U.S. at 159, 108 S. Ct. at 1697; Webb v. State, 533 S.W.2d 780, 784 (Tex. Crim. App. 1976) (holding). The court must indulge the presumption that the defendant has not been diligent in the search for an attorney.

Cf. Sands, Taylor & Wood Co. v. Quaker Oats Co., 978 F.2d 947, 963-64, 7th Cir. 1992) (holding as much).

We disagree. In her argument, the imposition of consecutive sentences for these two crimes constitutes multiple punishments for the same offense, in violation of her right to be free from double jeopardy under the United States and Virginia Constitutions. Hence, she concludes, the trial court erred in not setting aside the jury’s verdict and dismissing the conspiracy charge. As a general rule, however, the double jeopardy or as re doctrine does not bar the imposition of consecutive sentences for two crimes arising out of the same criminal act “unless the two punishments are ... for the same crime, or one punishment is for a crime which is a lesser-included offense of the other.” See also Brown v. Ohio, 432 U.S. 161, 167, 97 S. Ct. 2221, 2226, 53 L. Ed.2d 187 (holding that the double jeopardy rule does not bar consecutive sentences for two crimes arising out of the same criminal act).

In some cases, however, prejudice will be minimized by the fact that the party has notice of the need to adduce evidence in support of its Article III standing even though neither the court nor the defendant makes a formal motion. Similarly, to the extent that identical issues have already been raised in the litigation, the threat of prejudice is greatly diminished. In the present case, although defendants had not filed a motion to dismiss, they had alleged in their pleadings that the court would not have subjected them to the costs and delays inherent in a protracted trial. As a result, once an attorney forms a reasonable opinion after conducting appropriate research, it is not enough that the attorney’s view of the law was wrong. The mere fact that the attorney’s view of the law was wrong cannot support a finding of a Rule 11 violation. Sutliff, 846 P.2d at 1236 (citations omitted). Similarly, section 13–7–4(d) does not impose a duty on civil rights plaintiffs or their attorneys to conduct perfect or exhaustive research or to reach the correct legal conclusion. It is enough that their efforts and view of the law were reasonable. Our conclusion is consistent with the federal civil rights standard and those of several of our sister states. See Christiansburg Garment Co. v. EEOC, 434 U.S. 412, 421-22, 98 S. Ct. 1411, 53 L. Ed. 2d 776, 59 A.L.R.2d 142, 158 P.2d 712, 158 L.Ed. 880, 59 L. Ed. 821, 158 L. Ed. 876, 59 L.Ed.2d. ; Sees v. In making this concession, the state did not identify any particular source of law for its view, but we think that the source of law is (as the trial court held) Article I, section 16 of the Oregon constitution. The injunction that “excessive bail shall not be required” necessarily presupposes a factual inquiry into the issue of “excessiveness”; only a hearing can provide that factual inquiry. Upon such hearing, the trial court may consider the individual circumstances of a defendant. In view of these principles, we hold that any defendant who wishes to make an “as applied” challenge to the propriety of imposing the specified security release amount of fifty thousand dollars or higher under ORS 135.240(5) has a constitutional right to a hearing on that question. We hold that any defendant who wishes to make an “as applied” challenge to the constitutionality of the security release statute, ORS 135.240(5), has a constitutional right to a hearing to address that question. See Delaney v. Shobe, 218 Or. 626, 346 P.2d 126, aff’d.

A classic example of the importance of the appearance of a witness to the trial is the “he said, she said” trial, in which the victim testifies that the defendant committed a crime against her, and the defendant testifies that he did not commit the alleged crime. The proof in such cases is not merely inconsistent but is directly contradictory. In such a case, a successor judge would be unable to independently assess the weight of the evidence. Absent substantial proof that one or the other of the witnesses was simply lying, the demeanor of the witnesses would be a crucial component of evaluating their respective veracity. See, e.g., Biggs, 218 S.W.3d at 655 (holding). But most cases are not so straightforward.

We adopt the majority rule in cohabitation situations. This rule is essentially the rule we have adopted for remarriage, as explained in Taylor; and it is therefore perfectly in harmony with our current law and creates no disincentive to remarriage, which is a cause of concern in states where remarriage means an automatic termination of maintenance. It is worth noting the cautionary words of the North Dakota Supreme Court in Cermak v. Cermak, 1997 ND 187, 10, 569 N.W.2d 280: "The length of [the recipient's] relationship is unknown; it may last until her death or may break up tomorrow; in this case any support she may receive from her cohabitant is provided from her own goodness and does not imply any reciprocal or continuing obligation." See also Gilman, 956 P.2d at 765 (Supreme Court of Kentucky). As explained by the Kentucky Supreme Court, we adopt a rule which essentially follows the rule we adopted in Taylor, 773 F.2d 1256, 1315, 69 P.3d 1311, and we therefore find it appropriate to adopt a rule which follows the majority rule.

* * * * * The cases that come before the supreme State and Federal Courts will be resolved on other grounds, not on this debatable question of the impact of different legal rules on freedom of expression for performing artists. A more compelling argument for resolving the issue is that the legal limitations protecting freedom of expression are designed to serve primarily as a shield, not as a sword. They are generally invoked to protect freedom, and only rarely to support an action for damages. This is so because the legal system stands ready to protect freedom from unlawful governmental intrusion, but is reluctant to use the sword of damages to vindicate one claim of freedom by striking down another. Cf. NAACP v. Claiborne Hardware Co., 458 U.S. 886, 920-32, 102 S. Ct. 1571, 1573. In a system of equal justice, a conception of freedom of expression conceived in this way has a definite place.

A presumption of marital property arises in relation to all assets acquired during the marriage. These assets are subject to equitable division unless it can be shown by proof that these assets are attributable to one of the parties’ separate estates prior to the marriage or outside the marriage. Hemsley v. Hemsley, 639 So. 2d 909, 914 (Miss. 1994). 1 Ann Oldfather, Janice E. Kosel, et al., Valuation and Distribution of Marital Property,  3.03(4), 3-37 (1994 ed.). Commingled property is a combination of marital and nonmarital property which thereby loses its status as nonmarital property. 1 Ann Oldfather, Janice E. Kosel, et al., Valuation and Distribution of Marital Property, 3.03(5), 3-37. See also Boggs v. Boggs, 157 Ark. 190, 183 (Ark. Comm. Div. Ct. App. 1993). Kenneth cites the case of Johnson v. Johnson, 188 Ark. 187, 761 S.W.2d 956, 957 (Ark. Comm. Div. Ct. App. 1988) (en banc) (holding).

In this case, the district court primarily rested its discretionary decision on the possibility that Crime Stoppers' liability to Excellent Computation — and thus First Mercury's coverage liability — will never arise. See id. We acknowledge that “whether the judgment in the federal declaratory action would settle the controversy” is one factor that a district court may consider in deciding whether to exercise its discretion. Id. But that factor is insufficient, standing alone, to close the courthouse door; it must be weighed against the potential that an insurance coverage determination could “serve a useful purpose in clarifying the legal relations at issue.” Id. See, e.g., Britamco Underwriters, Inc. v. Central Jersey Invest., Inc., 632 So.2d 138, 141 (Fla. 4th DCA 1994) (holding otherwise). There is no indication that the district court viewed the declaratory action as any sort of “make-whole” proceeding.

Section 271f. See pp. 1372-74. We have more fully addressed the issue in Eolas Technologies, Inc. v. Microsoft Corp., 399 F. 3d 1325 (Fed. Cir. 2005). In that case, we held that Microsoft could not avoid its liability under section 271f by exporting master disks containing the software code that were subsequently copied onto hard disks and sold outside the United States. Our opinion on the issue did not elaborate further. Eolas involved both a product and a method claim. Id. at 1331, 1341. In holding that Microsoft was liable under section 271f, we held that the software code included on Microsoft's master disks was a “component” of a patented invention under section 271f, id. at 1339, and that the relevant “component” was the product claim. This case, by its terms, concerns only public figures. Opinion or a true statement of fact, or a statement that is false but was made without actual malice, cannot serve as the basis of an IIED claim by a public figure. Because I believe that the state's interest in protecting private individuals from the intentional infliction of emotional distress outweighs the First Amendment interest in speech about private matters involving private individuals, I would decline to extend Falwell to IIED claims brought by private figures like Carpenter. The State has a "strong and legitimate" interest in protecting private individuals from unprovoked verbal attacks. Private figures like Carpenter are both less equipped to defend themselves against attacks (holding) and less likely to become involved in controversy. Although he made the mistake of concluding that public figures are more susceptible to verbal attacks than private figures, I do not think it is too far-fetched to assume that private figures would be more so.

The Court interprets count four as asserting a right of recoupment in defense of the claim asserted by Morris in its Proofs of Claim. Section 558 of the Bankruptcy Code provides that the estate shall have the benefit of any defense available to the debtor as against any entity other than the estate, including statutes of limitation, statutes of fraud, usury, and other personal defenses. In order to avoid circular litigation or circular litigation, the Court will reconcile the amounts owed on both sides in the context of the Debtors’ claim objection. A waiver by the debtor of any such defense after commencement of the case does not bind the estate. Section 558, 11 U.S.C.  558. Courts have held that section 558 preserves to the debtor the defenses it would have had prepetition. In re PSA, Inc., 277 B.R. 51 (Bkrtcy.D.Del.2002) (holding a defense was not waived); In re Papercraft, 127 B.R. 397, 399 (Bkrtcy.D.Ill.1999). Count four was not timely.

Accordingly, the statute cannot mean that the one-year period begins to run from the date of the discovery of facts showing that the disposition of the asset may have been fraudulent as to creditors. To make the existing statutory term “transfer” carry such a meaning, we would in effect have to delete it and substitute some other phrase, such as “fraudulent nature of the transfer” or “facts constituting the cause of action.” It is not within our power to rewrite an unambiguous statute. See Hayes v. State, 750 So. 2d 1, 4 (Fla. 1999); FINR II, Inc. v. Hardee County, 125 So. 2d 248 (Fla. 1976); cf. De Los Santos v. Sosa, 164 So. 3d 1260, 1264 (Fla. 2d DCA 2015) (holding that rewriting statutes is not within the judicial function).

(A) holding that the court may not under the guise of statutory construction rewrite a statutory provision

(D) holding that the legislature may create or expand privileges by statute
(E) holding that a court may not rewrite the insurance contract under the guise of judicial interpretation

In Burch, we noted that: “The court has jurisdiction to revoke a defendant’s probation after his period of supervision has expired only if (1) the court has before the expiration of the probationary period a motion to revoke and (2) a warrant or capias issued prior to the expiration of the probationary period. Once these jurisdictional requirements have been met, they must be followed by proof by the state by a preponderance of the evidence that: (a) the defendant violated a term or condition of his probation; and (b) if the defendant is asserting due diligence at the revocation hearing, then (2) due diligence was used to apprehend the defendant, and (3) due diligence was used to hear the motion to revoke. See 622 S.W.2d 862, 863 (Tex. Crim. App. — Pol. — 1981) (holding). ” Id. at 387.

An offense qualifies under the ACCA’s residual clause if it poses a risk “comparable to that posed by its closest analog among the enumerated offenses.” Sykes v. United States, – U.S. –, 131 S. Ct. at 831; Holloway, – F. 3d at 257. In this case, Defendant has pleaded guilty to three violent felonies under Massachusetts law, two of which have been held by the First Circuit to qualify categorically as violent felonies, and a third of which clearly would qualify based on the holdings of the courts of that state. In 1989, Defendant pleaded guilty to larceny from the person, which qualifies as a violent felony under the ACCA. In 1990, Defendant pleaded guilty to assault and battery and attempted armed robbery, both of which also qualify as violent felonies under the ACCA. See United States v. Rodriguez, 659 F.3d 117, 119 (1st Cir. 2011) (holding as much).
Choices:

(E) holding categorical approach to determine whether a prior conviction qualifies as a violent felony for acca purposes raises no sixth amendment issue

"When a timely objection at the time of the admission of the evidence is not made, the issue is not preserved for review in this Court." Ziglar v. State, 629 So.2d 43, 47 (Ala.Crim.App.1993). State, 624 So.2d 230, 234 (Ala.Crim.App.1993), and Ex parte Crymes, 630 So.2d 125, 127 (Ala. 1993).

11 U.S.C.  362(a)(1) operates as a stay: “The commencement or continuation, including the issuance or employment of process, of an action or proceeding against the debtor that was or could have been commenced before the commencement of the case under this title, or to recover a claim against the debtor that arose before the commencement of the case under this title.” A stay is effected automatically when a bankruptcy petition is filed, whether a party to the litigation, or the non-bankruptcy court, is aware of the bankruptcy. See Paine v. Sealey, 956 S.W.2d 803, 805 (Tex.App.-Houston [14th Dist.] 1997, no pet.) (holding); Bates v. Pan Am. World Airways, Inc., 966 F.2d 457, 459 (9th Cir.1992) (same); cf. Evans v. E.F. Hutton & Co., 710 F.2d 1510, 1514 (E.D.N. 1113) (in re Evans); and Aspinall v. Exxon Co., 686 F. Supp. 1194, 1211 (W.D. Mich.1989) (same); The Stay provides the debtor with a remedy.

The record supports the district court’s conclusion that Officer Pierucci had lawful access to the cards. Pierucci could search the envelope and read the cards under the terms of the warrant, which authorized the seizure of cards in the name of Ogans or Joseph Williams. The Fourth Amendment rights were not violated. We affirm. The incriminating nature of the cards was immediately apparent to Pierucci. Because the cards’ incriminating nature was immediately apparent to Pierucci, the plain-view doctrine justified their seizure. See United States v. Ross, 456 U.S. 798, 820–21, 102 S.Ct. 2157, 72 L.Ed.2d 572. The fact that Officer DeJesus had seen the cards before Pierucci did not render the search unlawful. See Minnesota v. Dickerson, 508 U.S. 366, 375, 113 S.Ct. 2130, 124 L.Ed.2d 334. DeJesus’ request that his supervisor also see the cards did not render the search unlawful. See United States v. Ewain, 88 F.3d 689, 695–96 (9th Cir.1996) (holding).

Niehous argues that the reference to an annual salary, a bonus and 15 days of holiday, one year’s holiday, implies that the contract is for a minimum period of one year. Hence the language cannot rebut this presumption. This is based on the so-called English Rule, a previously recognized exception to the at-will doctrine. The English Rule provides that “a hiring at a stated sum per week, month or year, is a definite employment for the period named” (Dallas Hotel Co. v. Lackey, 203 S.W.2d 557, 561 (Tex.App.—Dallas 1947, writ ref’d) ( cited in Hamilton v. Segue Software, Inc., 232 F.3d 473, 478 (5th Cir. 2000) (HELDING). Therefore, this court must make an Erie-analysis of the contract.

(D) holding that use of annual salary rate created fact issue as to whether the employment contract was atwill or for a specific term
(E) holding that an atwill employment relationship is contractual and may serve as a predicate contract for a  1981 claim

In contrast to the cases above, Thomas was not charged with being a habitual offender under two different statutes. He was charged with being a habitual offender under Ind. Code 35-50-2-8 and with carrying a handgun without a license, which was a Class C felony. The fact that the handgun charge was elevated from a misdemeanor to a felony does not render the application of the habitual offender statute in any way duplicative. Because Thomas's convictions were not already enhanced by a specific habitual offender scheme, the use of the general habitual offender statute does not result in double enhancement. Hence, the State was not barred from using Thomas's 1981 robbery conviction as an underlying felony to support the habitual offender charge. See Haymaker v. State, 667 N.E.2d 1113, 1121 (Ind.1996) (holding to the contrary). See also Williams v. State, 676 N.E.2d 1074, 1076 (Ind.

In support of his claim, Godfredson does not allege any facts beyond those that support his claim of discrimination under the ADEA. But an employee’s termination, even if based on discrimination, does not rise to the level of “outrageous conduct” without proof of something more. (quoting Second Restatement of Torts  46, 1965). If this were not true, then every discrimination claim would simultaneously become a cause of action for intentional infliction of emotional distress. See Baab v. AMR Services Corp., 811 F. Supp. 1246, 1269 (N.D.Ohio 1993) (“To say that Ohio courts narrowly define ‘extreme and outrageous conduct’ would be something of an understatement.”); Bryans v. English Nanny and Governess Sch., 813 F. Supp. 1313, 1318 (D.D.N.Y. 1997). Godfredson’s testimony that Boo-kmyer had abused him and had mocked him is insufficient to establish the existence of the requisite intent.

The second issue is whether we have jurisdiction over CTF’s cross-appeal of the District Court’s stay, and if we do, whether we have jurisdiction over CTF’s appeal. CTF argues that a stay is not a final order because it is merely a temporary respite from litigation. We agree that a stay is not a final order, because it is only a temporary respite from litigation. However, when a stay effectively dismisses the underlying lawsuit, it may be subjected to appellate review. Marcus v. Twp. of Abington, 38 F.3d 1367, 1370 (3d Cir.1994). The Cheyney State College Faculty v. Hufstedler, 703 F.2d 732, 735 (3d Cir.1983) (citing Moses H. Cone Hosp. v. Mercury Constr. Co., 492 U.S. 656 , 682-83 (11th Cir.1979), and Pate v. Polsinello, 325 F.2d 158, 161-82 (2d Cir.1962)). We have also recognized that an indefinite stay, unless modified, may be subject to appellate review.

(E) holding that issues as to whether declaratory relief should be granted had become moot and would be dismissed for lack of jurisdiction but that under hallman the entire appeal was not moot because there still was a live controversy as to whether appellee was entitled to recover attorneys fees under the declaratory judgments act and therefore issues regarding attorneys fees were not moot and would be decided

ii. Qualified Immunity: Officers Smith and Herring plead the defense of qualified immunity. The standard for this defense is that government officials who perform discretionary functions are entitled to qualified immunity, which shields them from civil damages, provided that their conduct did not violate a clearly-established constitutional or statutory right of which a reasonable person would have known. In order to defeat a claim of qualified immunity, the plaintiff must plead and prove that the defendant violated such a right. Hoard v. Sizemore, 198 F.3d 205, 211 (6th Cir. 1999) (citation omitted). In general, there is not, and was not, at the time of the incident at issue, a clearly-established right for an arrested person to be free from handcuffs that are too tight. See Nemeckay, 894 F. Supp. at 165. However, it is well-established that where no right has been established, the court should grant qualified immunity.

(E) holding that defendants are not entitled to qualified immunity

TFW, Inc. v. Franchot, 572 F.3d 186, 194 (4th Cir. 2009) (quotation omitted). Hendrix argues that the holding in Hendrix I is based only on dicta from the Supreme Court in Johnson v. United States, 529 U.S. 694, 120 S.Ct. 1795, 146 L. Ed. 2d 727 (2000). However, as Hendrix himself concedes, other circuits of appeal have also relied on Johnson to support the proposition that a district court may extend a period of supervised release, even if it was previously revoked. “We consider ourselves bound by Supreme Court dicta almost as firmly as we are bound by its express holdings,” see Gaylor v. United States, 74 F.3d 214, 217–18 (10th Cir. 1996), and Hendrix I cited the relevant portion of the opinion. Thus, we follow Hendrix I and the Supreme Court's authority on this issue. See, e.g., United States v. Winfield, 665 F.3d 107, 112 (4th Cir. 2012) (quoting Johnson); United States v. Vargas, 564 F.3d 618, 622–23 (11th Cir. 2009) (same).

Second, Barr argues that he is not merely disputing a sentencing enhancement, but is contesting his conviction on the second gun charge, which is proper under section 2241. Finally, Barr argues that he is factually innocent of his second firearm conviction, because an element of the crime was not proved. R. cites only a miscited Second Circuit case and an unpublished district court opinion. The first objection is without merit because, even if the R&R did not properly cite any binding authority, it correctly identified the law in this Circuit: Subject matter jurisdiction under section 2241 is present only when the petition attacks the execution, rather than the validity, of the sentence. See, e.g., United States v. Barrtlet, 178 F.3d 34, 50 (1st Cir. 1999) (“We hold that a petitioner may not attack his sentence in a collateral attack on his conviction.”). Barr’s second objection is equally without merit.

The purchase money loan does not form the basis of the Millers’ complaint. The DTPA claim against BAC is based solely on their attempt to modify the loan. Aurora Loan Services, LLC, 787 F. Supp. 2d 451, 455 (E.D. Tex. 2011) (A “modification of an existing loan is analogous to a refinancing. As in Ayers, “[h]ere, the alleged loan is for the acquisition of an asset that is already owned by the plaintiffs, rather than for a new acquisition.”

The standard adopted herein accords with the objective of assessing whether a business or economic justification is legitimate. Vendors holding claims that are separately classified from other unsecured claims must be providing the debtor with genuine operational or financial benefits, and the preferential treatment offered to those vendors must be reasonably calculated to induce their continued support of the debtor. “absent a specific state statute to the contrary, constructive trusts cannot be properly invoked to gain super-priority over the bankruptcy trustee” followed neither state law nor bankruptcy law. 183 B.R. at 157, n. 7. He took the classic approach and decided that, under Illinois law, a party in Datacomp’s and Wilfarm’s position, lacking a judicially created constructive trust, had no equitable interest in the estate’s property. Id. at 157–160. How did the majority reach this result if, as Judge Barliant explained and I agree, it was not based on state law or the plain meaning of  541 of the Bankruptcy Code? I conclude that the majority’s rationale is solely bankruptcy policy. The bankruptcy policy is that a party claiming an equitable interest in the estate’s property must prove a special relationship to the property and show a specific and legitimate claim to the property. See Federal Land Bank of Louisville v. Glenn (In re Glenn), 760 F.2d 1428, 1436 (6th Cir.1985) (finding that a constructive trust was “not an equitable interest,” id. at 1436 (Hand, J.)).

(E) holding that the debtors were entitled to cure the mortgage arrearage through their chapter 13 plan because the creditors failure to record the sale deed prior to the bankruptcy filing rendered the sale incomplete under state law

The second common pattern arises where a creditor has repossessed property post-petition, and prior to the time the court’s notice of the pendency of the case has been received, but after the debtor or someone on the debtor’s behalf has informed the creditor that a case has been filed. Bankr., Bankr. S.D. Ga., June 24, 1997) (Davis, J.). If a creditor fails to make such an inquiry, and repossesses, it does so at its peril and may subject it to damages. See In re Marine Pollution Service, Inc., 99 B.R. 210, 211 (Bankr. S.D.N.Y. 1989) (holding). Finally, some repossessions, such as the present, arise from the failure of a creditor to honor a notice of default.

Whether or not one is entitled to use equitable estoppel as a defense against suit, existing cases suggest that it is. For example, in S.A.P., the court held that the State can be equitably estopped from asserting  768.28(13), Florida Statutes, which provides a period of four years from the accrual of a cause of action to commence suit against it, as a defense to an untimely claim. 835 So.2d at 1097-98. In reaching that conclusion, the court characterized 768.28(13) as a “conventional statute of limitations” and distinguished it from “a statute of repose that forecloses all forms of equitable relief.” Id. at 1100. The implication of that distinction is that, had the statute been one of repose, an equitable doctrine such as estoppel would not have spared the plaintiffs’ claim. See also May, 771 So.2d at 1161 (holding the same); Aristide v. Jackson Mem’l Hosp., 917 So.2d 144, 146 (Fla. 4th DCA 1999).

Attorney General Rusk argues that Local Law 69 is unreasonable because it charges manufacturers who sell or distribute cooling appliances in New York City for the City’s costs of disposing safely of the refrigerants in the same manufacturers’ appliances when they are discarded in New York City. This argument fails for several reasons. First, the fact that the law may incidentally encompass activities beyond the City’s limits does not render it unreasonable as a matter of law, especially given that Local Law 69 limits the coverage of the law to manufacturers who have availed themselves of the New York City market for cooling appliances. The stay entered in the Curtis bankruptcy case was void and of no effect, since it violated the automatic stay provision of 11 U.S.C.  362(a)(4)(1978). Under that subsection, the filing of a petition in bankruptcy operates as an automatic stay of “any act to create, perfect, or enforce any lien against property of the estate. . . .” The language of this subsection does not indicate that the mere filing of a continuation statement is to be included within its scope; such a filing does nothing more than continue the existence of a previously created, previously perfected, and concurrently valid security interest, and does not constitute an act to enforce or collect on a lien against property of the estate. See United States v. Sayres, 43 B.R. 437 (W.D.N.Y. 1984) (holding same); In re Chaseley’s Foods, 30 B.R. 452 (D.N.J. 1976) (same).

... The doctrine ... is an intensely practical one, founded on the realities of litigation in our adversary system. One of those realities is that attorneys must rely on the assistance of investigators and other agents in compiling materials for trial. It is therefore necessary that the doctrine protect materials prepared by agents for the attorney as well as those prepared by the attorney himself. Id. at 238-39, 95 S. Ct. at 1864. Accordingly, the federal courts have consistently ruled that the work product doctrine is not inapplicable to materials prepared by or for an insured party or the agents of the insurer. Supp. 37, 41 (E.D.N.Y. 1983), aff'd, 779 F.2d 38 (2d Cir. 1985) (holding that the work product doctrine does not apply to the documents in a subrogation proceeding).
