“Where the state court does not follow the Supreme Court on a question of law or where it decides a case differently from the Supreme Court on a set of materially indistinguishable facts, the State’s decision is not a binding precedent for the Supreme Court.” Williams v. Taylor, 529 U.S. 362, 412-13, 120 S. Ct. 1495, 146 L. Ed. 2d 389 (2000). A state court’s adjudication only results in an “unreasonable application” of clearly established federal law when “the State’s decision identifies the correct governing legal principle from our decisions but unreasonably applies that principle to the facts of the prisoner’s case.” Id. at 413, 120 S. Ct. 1495. Indeed, the Supreme Court has been increasingly vigilant in enforcing the standards of the AEDPA. See, e.g., Cullen v. Pinholster, -—U.S. -—, — S. Ct. 490, -—S. Ct. 598, -—S. Ct. 675 (Mar. 5, 2010); see also P. F., apr. 16, at 4. It is not enough for us to determine that the State’s decision violated the AEDPA in the manner it did.

When Sections 91.150 and 91.152 of the Ordinances authorize a maximum penalty of imprisonment for a period of twelve months, the same minimum penalty that is authorized by KRS 532.060(2)(d), the constitutional and public policy concerns would be immense. In any event, it is not the duration of the incarceration that offends the most basic notions of due process and liberty, it is the mere act of authorizing incarceration by an entity other than the State. The authority to enact laws depriving citizens of their liberty by imprisonment is the exclusive province of the sovereign, and in Kentucky that authority is non-delegable and, therefore, may not be transferred to local governments. In arriving at this determination, I agree with the reasoning in Board of Trustees v. City of Paducah, 333 S.W.2d 515, 518 (Ky.1960) (holding that the City of Paducah is not a “city” within the meaning of KRS 75.100).

Pattern analysis requires the extraction of body fluids, which is why the author clearly requires a warrant for that forced blood extraction, unless probable cause and other urgent circumstances, such as the rapid dissipation of blood alcohol evidence, allow. Besides, the pattern analysis is even more intrusive than the blood alcohol test, discussed in the article by Skinner and the author, which only revealed the current blood levels of alcohol and other behavior-altering substances. DNA genetic pattern analysis contains uniquely private facts about the individual, which should be subject to strict confidentiality requirements even broader than the protection of an individual's medical records. See Whalen v. Roe, 429 U.S. 589, 599, 97 S.Ct. 869, 876, 51 L.Ed.2d 64, 697 (1977) (holding). Individuals have a categorically unrestricted right to choose whether to reveal their DNA profile to law enforcement, or to refuse to do so.

In our view, the non-disclosure agreement, coupled with the allegedly improper concept of outsider trading, might lead to the filing of complaints solely for the purpose of extracting nuisance settlements. Although the plaintiffs do not cite the defendants' SEC forms in framing their allegations of insider trading, these allegations derive from the publicly available information. Kramer, 937 F.2d at 774. However, the attempt to exclude the defendants' SEC forms as hearsay is disingenuous for the same reason. Having raised questions about the defendants' stock sales, based their allegations on the defendants' SEC filings, and submitted expert declarations that rely on the SEC forms at issue, the plaintiffs cannot complain when the defendants use the same information in their defense. For these reasons, the court denies the motion to strike. See United States v. Anderson, 532 F.2d 1218, 1229–30 (9th Cir.1976) (holding).

A petition for bill of review must be filed after the expiration of the trial court's plenary power but within the four-year residual statute of limitations. To set aside a judgment by bill of review, the petitioner must ordinarily pleading and prove (1) a meritorious defense to the cause of action, (2) that the petitioner was prevented from making the defense by the fraud, accident or wrongful act of the opposing party, and (3) that the petitioner was not guilty or negligent. Griffin v. Gomez, 975 S.W.2d 535, 537 (Tex. 1998). However, if the petitioner was not properly served, constitutional due process relieves the petitioner from showing the first two requirements. Id. The third element is conclusively established if the petitioner proves that he was never served with process. Id. (HOLDING). In other words, the petitioner need not establish a meritorious defense, nor fraud, nor negligence.

In Day, the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals considered whether an independent expenditure trigger violated the First Amendment. Id. at 1360. The Day Court held that “the knowledge that a candidate one does not want to be elected will have her spending limits increased and will receive a public subsidy equal to half the amount of the independent expenditure as a direct result of that independent expenditure chills the free exercise of that protected speech.” In other words, the Day Court equated responsive speech with an impairment to the initial speaker. All other courts to consider the issue have either questioned Day’s logic outright or distinguished it on its facts. See, e.g., Daggett v. Commission on Governmental Ethics & Election Practices, 205 F.3d 459, 465 n.25 (C.A.9 ).

If a party wants a state court to decide whether she has been deprived of a federal constitutional right, she has to say so. The petition submitted at each level in the state court system has to make it clear that the petitioner is asserting the violation of the federal constitution that the petitioner subsequently asserts in the federal habeas petition. It cannot be conveyed entirely through allusions and connotations ... If she does not say so, she does not “fairly present” the federal claim to the state court. Thus the prisoner must “fairly present his claim in each appropriate state court... thus alerting that court to the federal nature of the claim.” Galvan, 397 F.3d 1198, 1204 (9th Cir.2005) (citing Baldwin, 541 U.S. at 29-32, 124 S. Ct. 1347) . See Lyons, id. at 668-70 (mere reference to “claim” was insufficient to fair present the federal claim.)

(D) holding that ineffective assistance of counsel constitutes cause for procedural default only if counsels performance was constitutionally ineffective
(E) holding that habeas petitioner failed to fairly present a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel by merely labeling counsels performance as ineffective without any accompanying reference to federal law or to a citation to an opinion applying federal law

“Probable cause to search exists when there is trustworthy information within the officer’s knowledge to lead a man of reasonable caution to believe that the instrumentality of a crime or evidence of a crime will be found.” Estrada v. State, 154 S.W.3d 604, 609 (Tex. Crim. App. 2005). In reviewing the evidence, we consider the “totality of the circumstances” known to the police at the time of the search. Illinois v. Gates, 462 U.S. 213, 229, 103 S.Ct. 2317, 76 L. Ed. 2d 527, 76 S.Ct. 2322, 76 L. Ed. 2d 555 (1983). The circumstances supporting a finding of probable cause may include flight or similar evasive conduct. See United States v. Macias, 546 F.2d 58, 61 (5th Cir.1977) (holding that flight was relevant conduct); Pyles v. State, 755 S.W.2d 98, 109 (Tex. Crim. App.1982) (holding that flight was relevant conduct).

(E) holding that where other evidence established probable cause to believe that the defendant possessed controlled substances investigating officers had probable cause to search the defendants purse for similar evidence

The FSHCAA of 1992 addressed the liability for medical malpractice not only of a health center but also of a health care physician or licensed or certified practitioner, designated as a part of the Public Health Service under 42 U.S.C.  254b(a)(l) and acting in the scope of his or her employment. The FSHCAA provided that the exclusive remedy for such liability would be against the United States under the FTCA. 42 U.S.C. 233g. In order to be protected from liability under the FTCA, a health center or an employee of such a center must be “deemed” by the Secretary of Health and Human Services to be an employee of the Public Health Service. 42 U.S.C. 233f, g. Under the traditional formulation of the FTCA, however, a “deemed” employee is an employee of the Public Health Service only if the Secretary deems him or her to be so employed. (Decision and opinion, March 13, 2003.)

The findings of fact show that the defendant misappropriated the sum of $31,487.50 of client funds kept in his trust account. This Court will not second-guess the referee’s recommended discipline, as long as it has a reasonable basis in existing case law and in the Florida Standards for Imposing Lawyer Sanctions. The referee’s recommended disciplinary action was upheld by the court of appeals, see Florida Bar v. Temmer, 753 So.2d 555, 558 (Fla. 1999). This Court has long held that attorney misconduct involving the misuse or misappropriation of client funds is unquestionably one of the most serious offenses a lawyer can commit. See also, Florida Bar v. Martinez-Genova, 959 So.2d 241, 246 (Fla. 2007). Indeed, disbarment is presumed to be the appropriate discipline when an attorney engages in this type of misconduct. This Court has also emphasized that the presumption does not mean that the attorney will be disbarred, rather the attorney can be suspended.

(At a cost-reimbursement contract, the government assumes all the costs incurred by the contractor during the performance of the contract, which gives rise to concerns about the government’s ability to control expenditures and limit its liability. LOC and LOF provisions are used to allow the government to increase funding or terminate a project in overrun status.) A fixed-price contract, by contrast, is not subject to the same funding concerns because the contractor must perform without regard to the cost of work within the scope of the contract or under a fixed-price, bilateral modification. A critical factor in the analysis of the limiting liability clauses is the ability of the contractor to cease performance upon reaching full funding. The Postal Service’s efforts satisfied the reasonable accommodation provision of Title VII. In the present case, the District Court imposed civil contempt on Yashinsky because the order compensated the plaintiff for its costs and expenses and imposed a daily fine in order to coerce Yashinsky to comply with the subpoena. A court may punish a party by using its contempt power, but contempt used as punishment is criminal, not civil contempt. Id. at 828, 114 S. Ct. 2552, citing Gompers v. Buck's Stove & Range Co., 221 U.S. 418, 441, 31 S. Ct. , 64 L. Ed. 1072, 1072, n. 3, 77 L. Ed. 188, 31 S. Ct. , 100 L. Ed. 1321, id. There is no later stage in which civil contempt can be transformed into criminal contempt, because an individual charged with criminal contempt is entitled to the same full procedural protections that are afforded to a defendant in any other criminal proceeding. See id. at 826, 833, 114 S. Ct. 2552 (holding). Therefore, Yashinsky is not required to produce the records.
Choices:
(A) holding the confrontation clause of the united states constitution does not apply at sentencing under the us sentencing guidelines manual and the procedural protections afforded a convicted defendant at sentencing are traditionally less stringent than the protections afforded a presumptively innocent defendant at trial
(B) holding that where criminal contempt charged has in it the element of personal criticism or attack upon the judge and where delay would not be impracticable a different judge should preside over the criminal contempt trial
(C) holding that constitutional protections afforded criminal defendants through the sixth amendment apply in nonsummary criminal contempt prosecutions just as they do in other criminal prosecutions
(D) holding that an individual charged with criminal contempt is entitled to the full procedural protections afforded the defendant in any other criminal proceeding
(E) holding that the district court committed reversible error by imposing criminal sanctions in a civil proceeding which did not afford the contemnor the procedural protections the constitution requires for the imposition of criminal contempt sanctions

What we have, then, is the following: assuming without deciding that Snyder was LFG’s attorney of record on October 9, 2008, we note that Chase Bank was served on September 19, 2008, and that the trial court signed the judgment in garnishment on October 10, 2008. App.. 663a (citing Requena, 2002 WL 356696, *3).

Although a defendant may collaterally attack a prior conviction used to enhance his sentence, no such collateral attack is permitted if the prior conviction is more than five years old. The district court allowed Baranda to attack the conviction for purposes of calculating his criminal history points, and the court sustained the attack. As a result, Baranda's criminal history points dropped to zero, and he became eligible for the so-called "safety valve" of 18 U.S.C. 851 (e). Baranda concedes, as he must, that he could not collaterally attack his prior conviction as the district court allowed. The court found that Baranda satisfied the requirements of the "safety valve" and sentenced him to 87 months. See United States v. Burrows, 36 F.3d 875, 885 (9th Cir.1994); Clawson v. The plaintiffs, now seeking damages from the court, all purchased their property from previous owners who had absolutely no knowledge of the contamination on their property. Since the prior owners received full value when the plaintiffs made their purchases, they did not suffer any harm from the undiscovered contamination. If the issue before the court was the statute of limitations, it would be easy to conclude that the plaintiffs’ causes of action did not “accrue” while the previous owners held title to the property, since the prior owners did not know, and could not reasonably have known, of the existence of their injury. (E) holding that a  1983 claim accrues when plaintiff knows or has reason to know of injury

Finally, the court has determined that plaintiffs have properly stated a claim for retaliation under the False Claims Act; therefore, the court will briefly address this argument here with respect to PhyCor individually. The plaintiffs have alleged that PhyCor owns/controls Straub and PhyCor, Hawaii (see Second Amended Complaint at 9: paragraph 17); therefore, PhyCor could potentially be liable for Straub’s retaliation. This argument lacks merit. Several circuits have held that vicarious liability applies to a principal corporation under the False Claims Act either when an agent of the corporation acts with apparent authority or when an employee acts within the scope of his employment for the benefit of the corporation. See, e.g., United States v. O’Connell, 890 F.2d 563, 569 (1st Cir.1989) (holding re: an agent’s apparent authority to retaliate against a whistleblower); Grand Union Co. v. United States, 696 F.2d 662, 664-65 (C.A.D.1980) (holding re: “Relevant CONFLICT TO RETAIN A PRINIUM WHICH CAN ENTITLE ITS OWNERS AND OWNERS. – AN ACT TO IMPOSE THEMOST IN A DIRECT MANNER OF PERSONNE CAPACITY.”).

(C) holding that claims of corporation vest in corporation
(D) holding that corporation will be liable under false claims act if agent acts with apparent authority even if corporation received no benefit from agents fraud
(E) holding that a corporation could be served by delivering a copy of the subpoena to an officer or managing or general agent of the corporation and that the agent could be an individual a partnership or another corporation

The Court, having reviewed Pacheco’s statements, concludes that the evidence Rivera presents either militates against or fails to substantiate Rivera’s claim that the prosecution promised Pacheco that he would be released on reduced bail, or that he was guaranteed immunity from prosecution. At most, Rivera has established by way of Pacheco’s state court docket sheets that Pacheco was in fact released on reduced bail within a week of testifying at Rivera’s trial. Pacheco’s ultimate bail reduction does not establish by clear and convincing evidence that the prosecution had struck a deal with Pacheco before his testimony, or that Pacheco’s release was anything but the “consideration” Pacheco had hoped. Cf. Shabazz v. Artuz, 336 F.3d 154, 165 (2d Cir.2003) (footnote omitted); see also Bell v. Bell, 512 F.2d 36 (2d Cir.1979).

MR. SHELBOURNE replied that in his professional judgment it was not useful to challenge certain evidence, as Mr. Howell wished, because it would be brought in later. The judge told Mr. Howell that Mr. Sheffield’s attitude was not uncommon in criminal cases and that it was not necessary to appoint new counsel. Mr. Howell has argued that the differences he had with Mr. Sheffield over the defense strategy created a conflict of interest which made it necessary for the trial court to appoint new counsel. However, the same cannot be said concerning the August notice and the suspension, and certainly not concerning the November notice and suspension. It is likely that harm became inevitable. By his willful failure to pay, each time Wright caused his employees to be left without insurance and courted the specter of termination. Not only were the actions of Wright deliberate and intentional, but they were also knowingly wrong, without just cause or excuse and substantially certain to cause harm. See Stelluti, 94 F.3d at 87. Even without any personal hatred, spite or ill will towards his employees, Wright's acts were both willful and malicious. Id. ; see also Leavitt, 451 F.2d at 66. In re Ussery, 179 B.R. 737, 740 (Bankr. S.D.Ga.1995) (holding). Like the appellee in Stelluti, though, he acted without any personal hatred, spite, or ill will towards his employees.

In limiting the decision to the facts of the case, the court stated that it was unnecessary to consider whether the statute required any other kind of relationship between the bribe and the expenditure of federal funds, because in this case the bribe was related to the accommodation of a prisoner in a cell which was partly financed with federal funds. Hence, the court left the question whether or not there must be some kind of relationship between the alleged theft or bribe and the expenditure of federal funds open. As a result of the Supreme Court's decision in Salinas, there has been a circuit split in the issue of whether there must be some kind of relationship between the bribe and the expenditure of federal funds. However, the fact that the defendant knew that white supremacists sometimes looked at his site and sometimes hurt people they considered enemies is insufficient to transform his lawful statements about juror A into criminal advocacy, that is, into advocacy directed to incite imminent unlawful action, as required by the First Amendment and by Section 373. Knowledge or belief that one’s speech, even speech advocating unlawful activity, may cause others to act does not remove such speech from the protection of the First Amendment unless such speech is directed to incite imminent unlawful activity and is likely to produce such activity. We lack jurisdiction to review Lopez Reyes’s other contentions, but we do so in any event.

The individual agent defendants - King, Munoz, Scarpiniti and Walker - all engaged in racial steering. The facts show that the four agents treated the blacks worse than the whites. The individual agent defendants are liable for compensatory damages. Agents King, Munoz, Scarpiniti and Walker, all whites, consistently steered whites to white areas and blacks to black areas. The four agents denied blacks access to information about the availability of rental accommodation, which they readily provided to similarly situated whites. The magistrate judge's conclusion that the different treatment was because of race is well supported by the record. We agree with the magistrate judge's conclusion that the individual agents violated the testator's rights under sections 1982 and 3604. See Dwivedi, 895 F.2d at 1533 (holding the same). Tolliver v. Amici, 800 F.2d 149, 153-154 (7th Cir. 1986).

Eight of the plaintiffs are organizations that sponsor, support or administer tobacco control programs and other cancer-related health initiatives. The import of asking the juror whether she could put the comment aside and decide the case based on the evidence and law given by the court is not inconsequential. Pennell, 737 F.2d 521, 533, 71 L. Ed. 2d 778, 737 F.2d 330, 335, 103 S. Ct. 940, 71 L. Ed. 2d 279 (6th Cir. 1984) (discussing Smith v. Phillips, 455 U.S. 209, 102 S. Ct. 940, 71 L. Ed.2d 78, 1982).) This court has also held that a juror’s assurance of continued impartiality is sufficient for her to continue serving as a juror. See Corrado, 227 F.3d at 537; see also United States v. Davis, 177 F.3d 552, 557 (6th Cir. 1999) (holding ).

– The three kidnapping purposes available to the jury to prove that Berry was murdered while being kidnapped are not so inherently distinct as to violate due process. The three underlying purposes of committing great bodily harm, committing murder, or facilitating flight after a third-degree assault are no more divergent than the predicate acts that may make up domestic abuse murder. They are not required to agree unanimously on which acts of abuse were committed for the purpose of domestic abuse murder. Stat. 609.25, subd. 2 (2004). While the legislature’s determination of penalties is not dispositive, it lends credence to assigning similar blame. (Holding , rev. denied, (Minn. Nov. 26, 1991) The underlying purpose is a factual one.

—Eymard v. Terrebonne, 560 So.2d 887, 890 (La. App. 1st Cir., 1991). The fear must be “reasonable” and must be of “unjust and considerable injury” to person, property, or reputation. —Id., writ denied, 567 So.2d 614 (La. 1990). There is no allegation by Witter that the actions of his creditors were unjust or unfounded in any way. —Id. Further, any emotional strain that Witter might have suffered as a result of his divorce is insufficient to establish legal duress. —Adams v. Adams, 503 So.2d 1052, 1057 (La. App. 2d Cir.1987). We conclude that the APD’s findings merely reflect a disagreement with the ALJ’s assessment of the evidence, not a finding on a factual matter infused with policy considerations. Such a disagreement cannot be the basis for reversing the ALJ’s factual determinations. For example, the APD’s order did not focus on anything Bridlewood did leading up to the sexual battery; rather, the APD focused on Tomlinson’s post-incident conduct. See Heifetz, 475 So.2d at 1281. But Tomlinson’s post-incident conduct was not the basis for the administrative complaint, and the APD cannot impose discipline for violations not charged. See Cottrill v. Dept. of Ins., 685 So.2d 1371, 1372 (Fla. 1st D.A. 1997) (holding). The APD’s final order was predicated on its conclusion that Tomlinson’s post-incident conduct, rather than his pre-incident conduct, constituted misconduct.

(E) recognizing that one of those conditions for a district judge to grant leave to amend the complaint may properly be that claims contained in the original complaint but not included in the amended complaint be considered dismissed with prejudice

If you are reading this, you must understand that the threat that can be posed to police officers is not necessarily the presence of a weapon in a vehicle. It is rather the imminent danger to police officers that a driver or a passenger may be allowed access to a vehicle that may contain a weapon or that is in a position to escape or overpower the officers on the scene. See Gamble, supra, 218 N.J. at 433, 95 A.3d 188. See also Lund, 119 N.J. at 48, 573 A.2d 1376. This standard governs this appeal. At a threshold matter, the record contains sufficient credible evidence to support the trial court's finding that, based on Officer Ceci's observations of the defendant's driving, there were specific and articulable facts giving rise to reasonable suspicion that the defendant had committed motor vehicle offenses and that the traffic stop was therefore lawful. See State v. Nishina, 175 N.J. 502, 512, 816 A.2d 489 (holding); State v. Lodi, 76 N.J. 225, 491 A.2d 621 (holding).

(D) holding that flight from police can help establish reasonable suspicion for an investigatory stop
(E) holding that a tip may provide the reasonable suspicion necessary to justify an investigatory stop

In summary, in two respects the Tiffany actions - namely, the use of the term 'Tiffany' in advertising and the purchase of the TIFFANY marks in generating sponsored links - are unsuccessful for the same reasons. First, the use of the word "Tiffany" in advertising is a protected, nominative fair use; second, to the extent that it is argued by Tiffany that this use is misleading, that argument rests on the assertion that the jewelry sold on the site is counterfeit. Though eBay certainly had generalized knowledge that the products sold on eBay were often counterfeit, it has not been proven that eBay had specific knowledge of the illicit nature of individual listings. Finally, to the extent that the advertising was false, the falseness was the responsibility of third-party sellers, not eBay. See Merck & Co., 425 F. Supp. 2d at 415 (holding). Consequently, there is no basis for concluding that the sponsored links were in any way misleading.

(D) holding that there is nothing improper with defendants purchase of sponsored links when defendants actually sell plaintiffs products  on their website
(E) holding that there is nothing improper about the use of a trademark to communicate that goods bearing that mark were actually sold on defendants website

New rules of criminal procedure are applicable to cases on collateral review if (1) they place “certain kinds of primary, private, individual conduct beyond the power of the criminal law-making authority to proscribe” (Id. at 311, 109 S. Ct. at 84), or (2) if they apply to all persons “without regard to race.” (Id. at 313, 109 S. Ct. at 1060), or (2) it “would be so central to the accurate determination of innocence or guilt,” id. at 313, 109 S. Ct. at 1060, that they would be “material to the determination of guilt or innocence.” The constitutional rule announced in Apprendi simply does not fit within either of these limited exceptions. (See Klein v. United States, 125 F. Supp. 2d 460 (D. Wyo. 2000) (Apprendi rule does not place conduct beyond the power of the criminal law-making authority or improve the accuracy of determining the guilt or innocence of a defendant); see also United States v. Quarterman, 2000 WL 1862684, 10th Cir., Aug. 15, —, — ).

In contrast to the situation in Brown, here, the payment of disability benefits was effected from Lumbermens’ own assets, and therefore such payments would not have a direct impact on KNS’s operating funds. Even in the case where the party making the benefits determination is the wholly-owned subsidiary of the insurance company responsible for paying the claims, the arbitrary and capricious standard would not apply unless “the plan-payout funding source retains ultimate control over the pay-out decision.” Williams, 373 F.3d at 1136 (quoting Allianz Life and Casualty Ins. Here, not only is there no allegation that the ultimate control of the decision to pay the claim rested with KNS, but also the plan-payout funding source, Lumbermens, was not under any contract obligation to ensure that Lumbermens’ disability benefits were paid out of Lumbermens’ own assets.

This is an appeal from the judgment of the Supreme Court of the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (“CNMI”), dismissing his claim that his constitutional rights were violated during the contempt proceedings before the CNMI Superior Court. Under 48 U.S.C.  1824, our jurisdiction over appeals from the CNMI Supreme Court is limited to cases involving the Constitution, treaties, or laws of the United States. We review de novo claims of due process violations, Bird v. Glacier Electric Company, 98 F. 3d 848 (11th Cir. 1991). The CNMI Supreme Court's conclusion that it lacked jurisdiction to review the trial court's original imposition of sanctions was based on local law, and we lack jurisdiction to review that conclusion. Moreover, Cushnie may not raise in this court his claim that the Superior Court exceeded its jurisdiction by acting as a rehearing court. Milne v. Reference is made to the Ohio statute cited in the preceding chapter for guidance in the interpretation of Ohio law. Gayer argues that she falls under the protection of the statute for disability discrimination because Continental regarded her as being so. She points out that Continental refused to hire her as an ASE because of her inability to lift more than 40 pounds. According to Gayer, this action constitutes evidence that Continental regarded her as being disabled. We disagree. For a covered entity to entertain misperceptions about an individual it must either believe that the individual has a substantially limiting impairment that the individual does not have or that the individual has a substantially limiting impairment when, in fact, the impairment is not so limiting. Sutton v. United Air Lines, Inc., 527 U.S. 471, 489, 119 S. Ct. 2139, 144 L. Ed. 2d 450, 145. But Gayer has not demonstrated that the latter is the case.

(E) holding that no ada violation was shown because the disabled were not denied benefits that were otherwise available

Rule 51. Upon the motion of the government made more than one year after the sentence has been imposed, a district court may reduce a defendant’s sentence based on substantial assistance if the defendant’s substantial assistance involved information: (1) not previously known to the defendant; (2) not useful to the government until more than a year after the defendant’s sentencing; or (3) the usefulness of which could not reasonably have been anticipated by the defendant until more than a year after the defendant’s sentencing. Ed. 2d 524, 121 So.2d 980, quoting as it does the government’s power to file a motion when a defendant has substantially assisted the government) . . . But unlike the defendant in the case of Terry, Golson testified in his own defense. The trial court erred in finding that the holding in the case of Terry controlled the evidentiary issue in this case, but this trial error is subject to a harmless error analysis. The number of Hispanics in Hamilton’s jury pool was 22. The percentage of Hispanics in his venire was 13.75% (22 of 160). (Appendix D omitted: Gerald Rocha and Mary Rodarte.) Finally, the BIA and the IJ erred in relying on Kumar's failure to present evidence to corroborate his attendance at Sikh religious institutions. We hesitate to affirm the adverse credibility finding solely on the basis of these differences in the affidavits. The IJ did not give Kumar a reasonable opportunity to explain the absence of corroborating evidence. For example, when the IJ asked Kumar why he had not brought a witness who could confirm his attendance at Sikh institutions in San Jose and Fremont, Kumar responded, “I haven't brought any, but I can bring any.” The IJ never asked Kumar to make good on his offer, but nonetheless relied on the absence of such a witness to find that Kumar lacked credibility. This was unfair. See Joseph v. Holder, 600 F.3d 1235, 1246 n.9 (9th Cir. 2010) (holding). Because “each of the [BIA's] . proffered conclusions is . based on . misrepresentations by . Kumar, . it would be a stretch” to find Kumar's statements untrustworthy.

The two petitions which were heard separately by the Administrative Judge, were consolidated on appeal to the Pleas Court. Judge Barry dissents. Judge X. reversed in part, and the petitions are dismissed. Stray voltage is a neutral current which cannot return to the utility substation through the distribution lines. Stray voltage is earthed by the utility and travels through the earth, returning on the distribution circuit. Stray voltage is dangerous because it can induce a low-voltage electrical shock when the equipment is not properly earthed. Stray voltage may also pass through the body of a cow, as part of the return circuit, depending in part on the moisture of the soil. [34 Pa. Cm. Ct. 516, 383 A.2d 997 (1978) (Helman)]

“The State cannot move for a new trial after the final forfeiture of the bond, and that such an attempt is a nullity. The court therefore concluded that the State did not have another adequate remedy for the court’s erroneous ruling. The question presented in the case of the State v. Sellers was whether the State may appeal in a bond forfeiture proceeding. To resolve this issue, the court examined constitutional and statutory history. The court found that the Texas Constitution of 1876 prohibited the State from appealing in criminal cases. Based on this prohibition, courts held that the State could not appeal in bond forfeiture cases, even though the statute explicitly permitted the State to appeal. The court cited State v. Ward, 9 Tex.App. 462, 463 (1880) and State v. Smith, 15 Tex.App. 318, 319 (1887) in this regard. The legislature, however, eventually acceded to the request of the courts and changed the law to allow the State to appeal.

The hearing was held within eight days of the incident having been reported. The prison regulations provide for a minimum waiting period of one day between notification and the IDC, and that the staff may suspend proceedings for up to two weeks in order to attempt an informal resolution. It is not claimed that the having two hearings before the hearing of the IDC deprived the prisoner of his rights. Therefore, the regulations did not create a reasonable expectation in having a hearing within less than eight days. Even if the regulations had stated that the prisoner was entitled to a hearing within less than eight days, the IDC's failure to meet this guideline would not alone constitute a denial of due process. The statute only applies to prisoners who are serving “a term of imprisonment” and imposes two significant limitations. First, the prisoner’s trial must be commenced, subject to certain tolling principles, in the receiving state within 120 days of his or her arrival in that state. Tenn. Code Ann., ch. 717, sec. 5. Second, the prisoner’s trial must be completed in the receiving state before the prisoner is returned to the “original place of imprisonment.” Tenn. Code Ann.  40-31-101, art. IV(c). If the trial is not commenced within 120 days of the prisoner’s arrival, or if the prisoner is returned or “shuttled” back to the original place of imprisonment before the trial is completed, the trial court is required to dismiss the charges with prejudice. B. Fox’s Notification Challenge is Properly Before the Court. The second half of Fox’s claim relating to the notification requirement of the statute, see 18 U.S.C. 4042(c)(2), is properly before the court as a petition for declaratory judgment. And since his administrative remedies are now exhausted, this claim can proceed. Notification claims do not relate to the fact or duration of his imprisonment and, accordingly, a challenge to the notification requirement is not properly before this court as a petition for habeas corpus. Hahn, 151 F.3d 116, 119–20 (3d Cir. 1998) (holding that notification requirement does not relate to the fact or duration of a prisoner’s imprisonment.)

A theft greater than twelve pence was considered grand larceny and was punished with death, though with benefit of clergy. The Fourth Amendment to the Constitution, “[T]he right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated” (U.S. Const., amend. IV). Plainly, a dog is not a person, a house, or a paper; therefore, in order for a dog to be protected by the Fourth Amendment, it must fall within the category of “effects.” Neither the Supreme Court nor the Fourth Circuit has ever addressed the issue whether dogs are “effects.” Three other circuits, the Third, the Eighth, and the Ninth, have considered whether dogs are protected by the Fourth Amendment. These circuits have uniformly concluded, although based only on eonelusory assertions, that dogs are indeed protected by the Fourth Amendment. See Brown v. Muhlenberg Twp., 269 F.3d 205, 209–10 (3d Cir. 2001) (holding that dogs are Fourth Amendment effects); Fuller v. Vines, 36 F.3d 65, 68–9 (9th Cir. 1994) (holding that dogs are Fourth Amendment effects); Bender v. Miss. Mich. Univ., 495 F.2d 976, 985 (D.C. Cir.1993) (holding that dogs are Fourth Amendment effects);
Choices:

The Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA), 28 U.S.C.  2671 et seq., provides a limited waiver of sovereign immunity for certain tort claims against the United States and its agencies. Section 2675 provides unequivocally that no claim under the FTCA may be brought unless the claimant has first filed an administrative claim with the relevant federal agency. This exhaustion requirement is jurisdictional and cannot be waived. Gregory v. Mitchel, 634 F.2d 199, 204 (5th Cir.1981). The plaintiff argues that a letter sent by its counsel to counsel for the FDIC on March 31, 1989, is sufficient to meet the exhaustion requirement. This argument must fail because the letter in question does not meet the “sum certain” requirement of Molinar v. United States, 515 F.2d 246 (5th Cir.1975). Also, the argument must fail because the FDIC has not yet acknowledged receipt of the letter.

The court-martial, with members duly instructed in the law, found the appellant guilty (among other things) of the offense of indecent assault, from which I dissent. In order to be convicted of an indecent assault, it is not necessary that the offensive touch itself be indecent. It is merely a simple assault committed by one with a prurient state of mind. There is no requirement that the accused actually satisfy his lust or sexual desires by the offensive touch. United States v. Hoggard, 43 M.J. 1 (C.M.A. 1995); United States v. Rodriguez, 31 M.J. 150 (C.M.A. 1990). In addition, evidence of other misconduct is admissible to show the requisite intent. United States v. Cox, 18 M.J. 72, 74 (C.M.A. 1984) (holding). In this case, the record shows that the accused had a sexually prurient state of mind.

The Horners assert that Section 510.265, the statutory cap on punitive damages, limits the award of damages for aggravating circumstances in a wrongful death case. They argue that the trial court erred in overruling their motion for remittitur. Section 510.265 provides, in pertinent part, that “No award of punitive damages against any defendant shall exceed the greater of: (1) Five hundred thousand dollars; or (2) Five times the net amount of the judgment awarded to the plaintiff against the defendant.” This is a question of first impression. (“Punitive damages” is not defined in Section 510.265.) The question of statutory interpretation is a question of law, subject to de novo review. We follow the holding in Hervey v. Mo. Dept. of Corrections, 379 S.W.3d 894, W.D. Mo. (2004.) As discussed in the discussion of Section 510.263, ante,  21, Section 510.265 does not mention aggravating or mitigating circumstances.

In this case the disputed constitutional question is whether the state of Washington can authorize the purchase and sale of real property. Although it is true that the Washington Supreme Court “has the exclusive, inherent power to admit, enroll, discipline and disbar [Washington] attorneys,” Short v. Demopolis, 103 Wash. 52, 62, 691 P.2d 163, 169, the same power does not preclude the Washington legislature from regulating “entrepreneurial aspects” of the practice of law which implicate the public interest. Short v. Demopolis, 103 Wash. at 65, 691 P.2d at 169. Indeed, requiring attorneys to comply with the DAA and the CPA when providing debt-adjustment services “is no different than applying other generally applicable statutes, such as the criminal laws, to attorneys.” Lang v. Daniel N. Gordon, P.C., 2011 WL 62141, at *3 (W.D. Wash. Jan. 6, 2011) (Holding). So, the Court concludes that requiring attorneys to comply with the DAA and the CPA when providing debt-adjustment services does not deprive the Washington Supreme Court of its exclusive power to admit, enroll, discipline, and disbar attorneys.

‘This petition concerns the venue in a district court of any matter involving a party who does not interpose timely and sufficient objection to the venue of the matter.’ 28 U.S.C.  1406 (b). In this case the Court finds that defendants have waived any objection to improper venue under 28 U.S.C. 1406 (a). The plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in August 2004. Although the plaintiffs amended their complaint in 2009, the current venue issue that defendants now raise was available and apparent at the time of the original complaint. (Compl.  2.) In 2005, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the complaint, raising several Rule 12 (b) defenses, including subject matter jurisdiction, personal jurisdiction, and failure to state a claim. The plaintiffs did not raise any objection to improper venue at this time. Even assuming the waiver standards of Rule 12 (c), see RSM Productions Corp. v. Fridman, 643 F.Supp.2d 382, 395 n. 7 (S.D.N.Y.2009) (‘Rule 12(c) Waiver’) , is applicable to this case, the Court nevertheless finds that any objection to improper venue was waived at the time of the original motion to dismiss.

The State correctly argues that the Helms case still controls the appealability of nonnegotiated pleas of guilty. See King v. State, 687 S.W.2d 762, 765 (Tex. Crim. App., 1985); Lynch v. State, 903 S.W.2d 115, 118 (Tex. App.—Fort Worth, 1995, no pet.). The Helms rule provides that where a guilty plea is entered and there is no plea bargain, all nonjurisdictional error occurring before the entry of the plea is waived. See Lynch, 903 S.W.2d at 116. However, there is no jurisdictional bar to appealing matters that follow a nonnegotiated guilty plea. The alleged error in this case occurred at the sentencing, almost three months after the plea. See Jack v. State, 871 S.W.2d 741, 744 (Tex. Crim. App. 1994). Therefore, we must address the merits of the appellant's point of error. Generally, the entry of a nolle prosequi on a misdemeanor charge tolls the running of the statutory speedy trial time until the service of a summons on a second misdemeanor charge arising out of the same conduct. Westlake v. Cougill, 56 Ohio St.2d 230, 10 O.O.O.3d 382, 383 N.E.2d 599. Similarly, the time between the entry of a nolle prosequi and the reindictment of a felony charge is excluded from the computation of speedy trial time. State v. Spratz, 58 Ohio St.2d 61, 62, 12 O.O.3d 77, 388 N.E.2d 751, 752, fn. 2. In both instances, however, “credit was given the accused for the period of time the charges based on the same conduct were pending prior to the entry of the nolle prosequi.” State v. Bonarrigo, 62 Ohio St.2d 7, 8, 16 O.O.3d 4, 402 N.E.2d 530, 534 (holding that to determine the speedy trial time remaining for the defendant, the pending charges must be added up.)

‘... the former panel, in the light of new developments, would change its collective mind.’ It is doubtful that this scenario can ever play out where, as here, a panel of a court finds its path blocked by an earlier decision of the full court. A contrary rule permitting a single panel in a multi-panel circuit to revisit determinations made by the court as a whole would invite chaos. Cf. Ewing v. Williams, 596 F.2d 391, 397, 430 (9th Cir.1979) (declaring that an appellate panel ‘simply cannot modify an en banc decision’). It follows that panels generally are precluded from following such a maverick course. Cf., e.g., United States v. Norton, 780 F.2d 21, 23 (8th Cir.1985); United States v. Poolaw, 588 F.2d 103, 105 (5th Cir.1979); cf. Biggins v. Hazen Paper Co., 111 F.3d 205, 208 (1st Cir.1997). In such a case, all roads lead back to Rome.

When a bank officer makes a statement or omission of material facts false at the time, and where that officer has not exercised reasonable care and diligence to see that the information dispensed is accurate, the bank may incur liability. It was the statute which required the police to use a certain type of confirmatory test in accordance with National Institute of Drug Abuse (NIDA) guidelines when testing for several types of drugs. It is the question whether the defendant knowingly drove the vehicle in such a manner and under such conditions as to be liable to cause death or great bodily harm. A number of courts have held that speed alone is not sufficient to support a conviction of homicide by automobile. The instruction in the self-defense case was very extensive and quite detailed. It was based on the fact that Brown was the only assailant. Our sister circuits have held that government policies that affect the profitability of a contract, but do not preclude performance, should not be considered "acts of government" for the purposes of the force-majeure clause. Such acts have only an attenuated effect on the contracts in question, at most making the performance of the timber contractors unprofitable. We hold that the phrase "acts of government" in the context of Provision B8.21 does not cover such acts. See, e.g., Langham-Hill Petroleum, Inc. v. S. Fuels Co., 813 F.2d 1327, et al., eds., 813 F.2d 1327, et al. ( Fourth Cir.1987) (rejecting claim for relief under force-majeure clause where the government of Saudi Arabia acted to cause a collapse in world oil prices, thereby making a contract unprofitable for one party); N. Ind. Pub. Serv. (Pennsylvania) Co. v. Carbon County Coal Co., 799 F.2d 265 ( Seventh Cir.1986) ("A force-majeure clause is not intended to encompass every form of governmental action or inaction that may affect the profitability of a contract.")

Since a litigant in the Court of Federal Claims must seek “actual, presently due money damages from the United States,” United States v. King, 395 U.S. 1, 3, 89 S. Ct. 1501, 23 L. Ed. 2d 52, see also United States v. Testan, 424 U.S. 392, 96 S. Ct. 948, 47 L. Ed. 2d 114, I cannot bring myself to mention the case of A.J.H. Because, although the Court of Claims has jurisdiction to hear claims against the United States, it is equally clear that the Tucker Act does not itself create a cause of action against the government. The Constitution, statutes, regulations, and even treaties can, but it is not enough to point to a money-mandating constitutional provision, statute, regulation, or contract with the United States to give rise to a money-damages cause of action in the Court of Claims. See United States v. King, 650 F.2d 1068, 1081 (Ct. Cl. 1980) (holding the opposite); see also Walton v. United States, 213 Ct. Cl. 755, 758 (holding the opposite).

(D) holding that the claims court has no jurisdiction under the tucker act over claims to social security benefits
(E) holding that claims based on the fifth amendments due process and equal protection clauses do not give rise to jurisdiction under the tucker act

B. Subsection 1322(c)(1) and Foreclosure Sales Under West Virginia Law. Section 1322(c)(1) provides that a default with respect to a lien on the debtor’s principal residence may be cured until such residence is sold at a foreclosure sale. ... A debtor may seek to cure a default under section 1322(c)(1) and conclude that the right to cure a default terminates when the hammer falls at the sale. Some courts have recognized that this plain-language reading of the statute is at odds with its intent as expressed in the legislative history and, therefore, have adopted a more expansive reading requiring an examination of state law to determine when the property is actually sold. In re Beeman, 235 B.R. 202 (D. Mass. 2002). Christian v. Citibank, F.S.B., 214 B.R. 352, 362 (D.N.H. 1999) (Holding that a debtor may cure until the sale is actually consummated under state law); Doe v. Jollott, 202 B.R. 154, 165 (D. Ariz. 1998) (similar).

The substantial compliance with the requirements for the status of a conditional permanent resident, even if it were true, cannot excuse the failure of the plaintiff to maintain a full course of study in accordance with his status as a student. The intentions to be a conditional permanent resident and a non-immigrant student are mutually exclusive; the first involves a desire to stay in the United States permanently, the second does not. Moreover, the two sets of requirements are separate and independent. 8 C.F.R.  245 and  214.2(f). Substantial compliance with the requirements of the status of a conditional permanent resident does not constitute substantial compliance with the requirements of a non-immigrant student. See Ghajar v. United States, 652 F.2d 1347, 1348, 1351, 1352 ( 9 Cir.1981) (holding). Here, the plaintiff violated specific regulations.
Choices:

(C) holding that substantial compliance is sufficient to satisfy the notice requirements of sdcl 3212 and 3
(D) holding that substantial compliance with notice is sufficient
(E) holding that substantial compliance with the requirements for exempting a lessors personal property from a lien is not enough

Wife next argues that the trial court failed to consider all the marital assets in its division of marital property. Wife contends that the 1993 Dodge Caravan was her separate property, and that the trial court failed to consider certain items that husband purchased after separation. Wife argues that the Dodge Caravan was her separate property because husband gifted it to her. However, wife listed the Dodge Caravan as marital property on her First Amended Financial Statement. The rule that opens the door to marginal plaintiffs after the settlement would virtually force the defendant not to settle until all possible claimants had been brought into the action or until the statute of limitations had run. This behavior would obviously make it more difficult to prosecute antitrust violations and “undermine the effectiveness of treble-damages suits.” Associated General, 459 U.S. at 545, 103 S.Ct. at 545. The present suit would also expose the defendant to the risk of multiple liability, which the Court has emphatically rejected. Illinois Brick, 431 U.S. at 730–31, 97 S.Ct. at 912. See also id. at 2066–67 (citing Hawaii v. Standard Oil Co., 405 U.S. 251, 264, 92 S.Ct. 885, 892, 31 L.Ed.2d 184, 2066). The controlling factors under Associated General, 459 U.S. at 544, 103 S.Ct. at 2067, were not present here, and hence, the rule set out above must be rejected.

These plaintiffs also argue that WhenU’s use of their marks in the WhenU Directory constitutes a “use in commerce.” The use of the plaintiffs’ trademarks in WhenU’s scrambled Directory is not a use in commerce. The listing of the plaintiffs’ marks in WhenU’s proprietary Directory is done to identify the category of the participant’s interest, such as mortgages, and to send a relevant advertisement to that consumer. The displayed advertisement does not bear the plaintiffs’ trademarks; to the contrary, it bears WhenU’s marks and branding, as well as the marks and branding of the advertiser. The SaveNow software only uses URLs to identify the web site itself, much as one would use the word “Macy’s” to describe the Macy’s department store. (Sean O’Reilly v. W. B. Everyone had focused on the word “corruptly” as the key to what may or may not be lawful in the situation presented. Section 1512(b) does not only punish for “corruptly persuading” someone, but for “knowingly persuading” someone. (Emphasis added.) The Government suggests that “knowingly” does not modify “corruptly persuades,” but that is not how the statute most naturally reads: It provides the mens rea —“knowingly”—and then a list of acts: “uses intimidation or physical force, threatens, or corruptly persuades.” We have recognized in similar statutory language that the mens rea at least applies to the acts that immediately follow, if not to other elements down the statutory chain. See United States v. X-Citement Video, Inc., 513 U. S. 64, 68, 1994.
Choices:
(A) holding that the term knowingly under  2252a applies to both the nature of the material and the age of the children depicted
(B) recognizing that the most natural grammatical reading of 18 u s c  2252a1 and 2 suggests that the term knowingly modifies only the surrounding verbs transports ships receives distributes or reproduces
(C) holding that the offense defined by sections 2201a1 and b2b has three parts two of which include culpable mental states and that intentionally knowingly or recklessly in the third part modifies impeding the normal breathing or circulation of the blood of the person
(D) holding that unless otherwise directed by the statute the term knowingly merely requires proof of knowledge of the facts that constitute the offense
(E) holding that to determine whether a statement was voluntary the court must consider the totality of all the surrounding circumstances  both the characteristics of the accused and the details of the interrogation and decide  whether a defendants will was overborne by the circumstances surrounding the giving of a confession

The April 26 document stated an estimate of ‘roughly 5,000 barrels’; yet, on April 28, Suttles said BP’s best estimate was only 1,000 barrels. A question to a witness about a previous investigation was improper because “clearly the testimony the State was attempting to elicit from the witness was highly prejudicial and irrelevant in this case.” Field, 144 Idaho at 572, 165 P.3d at 286. We find that the testimony the prosecutor was attempting to elicit from Mr. Hartmann was similarly highly prejudicial and irrelevant. While the prosecution claims that the question was relevant to rebut anticipated attacks on Mr. Hartmann’s character and credibility by the defense, by establishing that Mr. Hartmann was not fired for poor performance, the character and credibility of a witness may not be supported until there has been an attack. Id. Nisi means “unless,” so a judgment nisi is valid unless a party acts to cause it to be withdrawn. 273 S.W.3d 157, 163 (Tex. Crim. App. 2008). Similarly, a withdrawal notification issued pursuant to Section 501.014(e) triggers a withdrawal of funds from an inmate’s account, serves as notice of the collection proceeding, and continues to operate unless the inmate takes action to cause the notification to be withdrawn. Therefore, rather than refer to that document as an “order,” we prefer to use the term “withdrawal notification” to avoid confusion with an underlying court order or judgment ordering the payment of a sum falling within at least one of the six priority categories listed in the statute. In Arizona, the rule is that, in the usual case, we will support the discretionary ruling of the trial court on the admissibility of expert testimony on eyewitness identification. Nor do we invite the opinion of experts on the subject in even the most extraordinary case, on the likelihood that a particular witness is correct or mistaken in his identification, or that eyewitness identification in general has a certain percentage of accuracy or inaccuracy. If these words were not clear enough, we are now saying explicitly that the trial court should not admit direct expert testimony that quantifies the probability of a witness's accuracy. 135 Ariz. at 297, 660 P.2d at 1224 (emphases in original). So, even if the trial court admits expert testimony on eyewitness identification in the unusual case, it may be only in the form of a statement of the trial court, such as in State v. Buell, 22 Ohio St. 3d 124, 489 N.E.2d 795.

(D) holding that the trial court did not err by failing to instruct the jury to consider certain additional factors in evaluating the validity of eyewitness identification testimony
(E) holding no abuse of discretion to exclude expert eyewitness identification testimony where governments case relied on more than eyewitness identification

Hayes appeals pro se from the district court's judgment dismissing his claim under  1983 that prison officials violated his constitutional right of access to the courts by denying him adequate access to the law library during lockdown. Officer Jones’s direct question as to the ownership of the gun was the only part of the statement suppressed, because it was not made in response to interrogation. The Supreme Court has defined interrogation as “words or actions on the part of police officers that they should know are reasonably likely to elicit an incriminating response.” (Rhode Island v. Innis, 446 U.S. 291, 302, 100 S. Ct. 754.) ' The officers here, except for Officer Jones’s question, asked no questions about the gun or gun ownership, and took no actions that were likely to elicit an incriminating response. A declaration of an express trust of land must be in writing. South Carolina Code Ann.  62–7–101. Nevertheless, “sufficient part performance of a parol contract for the conveyance of land will remove the contract from the statute of frauds.” Stackhouse, 271 S.C. at 521, 248 S.E.2d at 488. To compel specific performance of an oral agreement where part performance is alleged to remove the contract from the statute of frauds, a court of equity must find: (1) clear evidence of an oral agreement; (2) that the agreement had been partially executed; and (3) that the party who requested performance had completed or was willing to complete his part of the oral agreement. See Stackhouse, 271 S.C. at 521, 248 S.E.2d at 483. Consequently, the circuit court did not err in finding that the facts of this case satisfied all three of these elements.

Insufficiency of evidence is fatal to the requisite analysis of the certification criteria, as required by rule 23, which a trial court must conduct before certifying a class action. See Citicorp, 715 So. 2d at 204 (requiring a trial court to conduct a rigorous analysis of certification criteria). In this case, the insufficiency of evidence is reflected in the trial court’s certification order, which merely recite the requirements of rule 23, and summarily concludes that both the requirements of typicality and adequacy are met. The order simply recite the requirements of these criteria and summarily concludes that both prerequisites are met. As a result, the St. Clair County Circuit Court abused its discretion in certifying the class in the underlying action. See Ex parte American Bankers Life Assurance Co., 715 So. 2d 186, 189 (Ala. 1997) (“The Birmingham Water Works and Power Company, a monopoly engaged in distributing water throughout the state of Alabama, is subject to both the law and the rule”).

“The application of an enhancement ... does not implicate the Supreme Court’s holding in Apprendi v. New Jersey.” (United States v. Reyes-Vencomo, No. CR 11-2563 JB, 2012 WL 2574810, at *3 (D.N.M. Mar. 2, 2012)). The Tenth Circuit has stated that “the jury’s determination of a fact must be based on a determination that the fact in question will increase the defendant’s sentence above the statutory maximum permitted by the statute of conviction.” United States v. Price, 400 F.3d 844, 847 (10th Cir. 2005). (United States v. Price, 2012 WL 1868823, at *2 (D. Mont. June 26, 2012)) (Browning, J.). A defendant may assert an error under Apprendi v. New Jersey only if the fact at issue increases his sentence beyond the statutory maximum. Accord United States v. Ray, 704 F.3d at 1314. See also United States v. O’Flanagan, 339 F.3d 1229, 1232 (10th Cir. 2003) (holding that the government may increase a defendant’s sentence by inflating facts based on her conduct to evade the statutory maximum), United States v. Hendrickson, 592 F.3d 1194, 1197 (D. Mont. ), 794 F. Supp. 2d 130, 132 (D. Mont. ), and United States v. Reyes-Vencomo, see United States v. Reyes-Vencomo, 895 F.2d 1148, 1149.

Jupiter Capital N.B.S.C.'s transfer to the right to reclaim the commission on the first sale, and that it is bound to look to South Carolina contract law in coming to that conclusion. When construing a contract, the Court must first look to the language of the contract to determine the intention of the parties. When the language of the contract is plain and unambiguous, the court cannot modify it. Lewis v. Omni Indem. Corp., 58 F.3d 1041, 1046 (4th Cir.1995) (applying South Carolina law). If the language contains both specific and general terms, then the court must interpret the general language to include “only persons or things of the same general kind or class as those enumerated,” rather than to broaden the specific term. In re Jupiter Capital N.B.S.C., Inc. v. Saluda Cattle Co., Inc., 970 F. Supp. 2d 437, 451 (D.S.C.2013) (holding). If the contract contains both general and specific terms, then the Court must apply the broader term to include both the general and the specific term.

The ballot title of any amendment or other public measure shall be printed in clear and unambiguous language on the ballot. This Court has never held that, where an appellant fails to obtain a stay, and the property sought is conveyed in good faith to a third party, the appellant is entitled to return to the trial court and have damages awarded to him, if he is successful on his appeal. Neither the Richards nor the dissent has cited a single case in which this occurred. And they could not, because other jurisdictions have addressed this issue and have denied such a remedy. For example, the Illinois Appellate Court has held that “[i]n the absence of a stay, an appeal is moot where possession or ownership of specific property inextricably intertwined with the relief sought on appeal has been conveyed to third parties.” Horvath v. Loesch, 87 Ill.App.3d 615, 43 Ill.Dec. 154, 157, 410 N.E.2d 154, 157 ( citing cases). This holding is consistent with numerous cases in other jurisdictions.

In these circumstances, and especially where the party seeking to avoid the preclusion of the claim was the plaintiff in the prior action and the sole source of the error in naming the wrong party, res judicata should bar the plaintiff from gaining a second opportunity to litigate the very same claims, even where the identity of the parties is not complete. See Amalgamated Sugar Co., 825 F.2d at 640; see also Expert Electric Co. v. Levine, 554 F.2d at 1233 (holding as much). Although the Second Circuit has not, to our knowledge, addressed the issue of the applicability of res judicata in such circumstances, we conclude that the doctrine should apply in the instant case.

The State argues that the record was sufficient to show that Boyd conspired with an unknown drug supplier in New Orleans. We are not persuaded. The record was clearly sufficient to show that Boyd was a drug dealer and that he distributed crack as charged in the indictment, but it did not show that he engaged in a conspiratorial agreement to violate the drug laws. The only motive apparent from the testimony of the three women who testified against Boyd was their desire to buy drugs from him. None of the three women indicated that she worked for Boyd, solicited drug sales on his behalf, or otherwise acted in concert with Boyd to achieve a common purpose other than her desire to buy drugs from him. See United States v. Cardenas, 9 F.3d 1139, 1157 (5th Cir.1993); see also United States v. Mitchell, 484 F.3d 75, 77 (5th Cir.2007) (holding).

The Movant's counsel's strategy was to resolve the federal charges before the state court charges so that any sentences imposed on the state court charges could be run concurrently with the sentences imposed on the federal charges. In the instant case, there was no evidence offered that the Appellant worked in conjunction with anyone else to commit the crimes. See Masaka, 4 So. 3d at 1286; Wells, 967 So. 2d at 419. Where no evidence was offered that the Appellant acted with anyone to commit the crimes, the trial court erred in giving the instruction on principals. Such a theory was never argued before the jury and the instruction on principals was neither requested by the State nor read in the original reading of the jury instructions. The instruction was given only after the jury questioned the court on whether the Appellant was the actual shooter. I. Criminal Rule 4 (c): I differ from the majority in its attribution of several periods of time to the rule 4 (c) clock, rather than to Larkin. I also disagree that the trial court properly granted his motion to dismiss on constitutional grounds. First, while I fully agree with the majority’s analysis that the time during which the interlocutory appeal in Larkin I was pending was attributed to Larkin, I conclude that time did not run until the clerk of this court certified our decision as final on November 20, 2015. Ind. Appellate Rule 65 (E) states in part: The clerk shall certify the opinion or memorandum decision to the trial court or administrative agency only after the time for certification has expired. When the clerk . . . certifies the opinion or memorandum decision, all Petitions for Rehearing, Transfer, or Review are terminated, and all Petitions for Rehearing, Transfer, or Review are dismissed. (Ind. Ct. App., 2003) (HONORING) I concede that our supreme court in recent years has used a more liberal interpretation of this rule.

Id.  12. Here too, it is the same thing. If the use of the land were restricted to “a small, select number” of individuals chosen by the foundation for “their own reasons,” then the property was not put to “public use.” Those who wish to benefit from the use of the VSC’s property must make application, and the VSC has sole discretion in deciding who is entitled to the use. This is the same as with applicants to the Wild Land Trust in Vermont. That the application process is open to “the entire world” is no matter. What matters is the screening process itself, and the restrictions it imposes on those who may benefit from the primary use of the property. This is the hallmark of a “private” as opposed to a “public” use. See Sigler, 174 Vt. at 134, 807 A.2d at 447 (holding). As both the parent and child’s interests in the parent-child relationship are great, so is the State’s interest in resolving matters on appeal that have already been fully litigated, and reducing the time all parties must wait in litigation limbo until their case is finally resolved. If the jury could find that Metro could have committed an adverse employment action against Tuttle by issuing an unfavorable job performance appraisal and/or by terminating the plaintiff; and if so, what are the appropriate damages, if any. As Metro itself points out, a negative performance evaluation does not constitute an adverse employment action unless it has an adverse effect on an employee’s wages or salary. City of Albuquerque Police Dep’t, 190 F.3d 1304, 1309 (10th Cir. 1999) (holding that the “reputation” of a police officer who wrote an article critical of a newspaper article on police brutality was a “substantial motivating factor” in the officer’s termination).

Stacy Danley's counterclaim is a nullity because he failed to pay the filing fee for it in the state court. It's a harder call with Stephanie Danley because she did not claim money damages. Not only unjust, but also inconsistent with the underlying policies of the patent law, to base a determination that A&E infringed the patent on information that was not part of the public record at the time A&E designed the 735 model, regardless of whether this information substantively alters the claims of the original patent. See Stairmaster Sports/Medical Prod. Inc. v. Groupe ProCycle, Inc., No. 97-396(MMS), 1998 WL 290296 (D. Del. May 15, 1998), which holds that under the revised specification, a defendant may now assert as a defense a pre-existing factual dispute. In a modification of a lease agreement the rent payable must be stipulated; otherwise the contract has been altered. Perillo et al., Corbin on Contracts  4.3, at 568 (rev. ed., 1993); see also Pingree v. Continental Group of Utah, Inc., 558 P.2d 1317, 1321 (Utah 1976). ( See, e.g., Campbell, 144 Idaho at 257, 159 P.3d at 894; Martin, 133 Idaho at 375-376, 987 P.2d at 926 (holding)); see also Richardson, 104 Idaho at 672, 7 P.3d at 165 (same holding).)

Several of the cases on which the plaintiffs rely all involve elected officials of political subdivisions, such as cities and towns, which do not raise similar separation-of-power concerns. The Coleman v. Miller case, on which the plaintiffs also rely, is equally unavailing: there, the Supreme Court held that twenty-one senators from the State of Kansas had standing to challenge the constitutionality of a vote on a proposed amendment to the United States Constitution, based on their claim that a tie-breaking vote by the State's lieutenant governor did not represent ratification by the State legislature, as required by Article V of the United States Constitution. As the Supreme Court more recently explained in Raines v. Byrd, 521 U.S. 811, 823 (1997), the case stands “at most” for the narrow holding that “state legislators have standing to challenge an action taken by the national legislature in a manner that conflicts with the tenets of the separation-of-powers doctrine.”

“A legitimate expectation of privacy is one that society is prepared to recognize as ‘reasonable’. The legitimacy of an expectation of privacy is not dependent on the subjective intention of the individual who asserts the right, but on whether the expectation is reasonable in view of all the circumstances surrounding the case. Moreover, a decision on whether an expectation of privacy is legitimate or reasonable requires a balancing of interests.” 620 A.2d at 1118 (Citations omitted). “Here, Mr. Cass obviously intended to keep the contents of his locker private from the public. It was locked, and this fact would indicate that he intended to keep the contents private. The mere fact that he did not own the locker does not preclude him from having an actual expectation of privacy. See Bridge, supra (holding).” 620 A.2d at 1119; Commonwealth v. Gordon, 433 Pa. Super. 697, 716 A.2d 408 (Pa. Super. 1991); see also, Miller, et al., id. 157, 69 A.3d 894 (Pa. Super. 1992).

The claim fails because the procedures used in relation to the photograph were not unduly suggestive. Tynice Teague had seen Muller several times in the past and identified him as the driver of the truck in a six-photo array during an interview with police in a restaurant on 13 May 2012. As the defendants’ expert on the psychology of memory and eyewitness identification testified at the trial, the photo array contained five photographs similar in appearance to Mr Muller. (App. 2272.) This is the proper procedure for carrying out an identification. See, e.g., United States v. Burnett, 773 F.3d 122, 133-34 (3d Cir. 2014) (discussing the procedures used in a photo array to determine whether an identification is reliable and admissible). These procedures were not unduly suggestive, and the District Court did not err in admitting Tynice Teague’s identification of Muller. Muller also argues that the photo should be suppressed under Rule 9 of the Rules of Evidence.

Ofac raises interesting arguments concerning issues that we need not and do not decide. We address only the facts of this case, OFAC’s seizure of assets as a result of its designation order of a domestic entity. We do not address the Fourth Amendment requirements of other situations, including, for example, designations of foreign entities or designations by executive order. We note, moreover, that a designation order need not specify every detail about every asset in order to meet the Fourth Amendment’s particularity requirement. Although we have never held that a right of rescission exists under ERISA for insurance contracts entered into under a false representation of health, it is clear that such a remedy should exist. Seventy years ago, the Supreme Court stated that “(a) insurance policies are traditionally contracts uberrimae fidei and (b) the failure of the insured to disclose conditions affecting the risk of which he has knowledge renders the contract voidable at the option of the insurer.” Stipcich v. Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., 277 U.S. 311, 316, 48 S.Ct. 512, 72 L.Ed. 807 (1928). We need not decide whether uberrimae fidei itself still applies to ordinary insurance contracts, because many federal courts facing insurance issues have identified a right of rescission. See, e.g., Davies, 128 F.3d at 943-44 (holding); see also, e.g., Hauser v. Life General Sec., Inc., 6 F.3d at 995 (holding); see also Curtis v. Anheuser-Busch, Inc., 59 F.3d 347, 351 (1996). Accord Fisher v. Allstate Ins. Co., 56 F.3d 50, 57-58 (11th Cir.1995), which applied a New York law.

There are countless reasons why it may be important for a constable to tell a pedestrian to “move on,” and even if it were possible to list all the known reasons in an ordinance, many are simply unpredictable. Hence the perfectly reasonable rule in New York City, which reads: “No person shall fail, neglect, or refuse to comply with the lawful direction or command of any police officer, urban park ranger, parks enforcement patrol officer, or other (recreation) department employee, whether indicated verbally, by gesture, or in any other manner.” 56 RCNY  1-03 (c) (1) (1996). It is one thing to uphold an “as-applied” challenge when a pedestrian disobeys such an order that is unreasonable, or even when a pedestrian asserting some true “liberty” interest (but see, e.g., S.L., 325 U.S. 571) disobeys such an order that is reasonable but nevertheless violates that interest.

The employee alleges that she was subjected to demeaning and sexist comments from her male co-workers and that male co-workers interfered with various aspects of her work. Although Boeing claims that the basis for such comments was unrelated to her gender and instead was because her co-workers disliked her, “a counterweight is not enough to eliminate the need for a fact-finder to weigh the facts on both sides.” Davis v. Team Elect. Co., 520 F.3d 1080, 1093 (9th Cir. 2008). In our view, the EEOC also raises a genuine issue of material fact as to whether Boeing adequately responded to the employee’s complaints of harassment. Although Boeing did fire one offending male employee and disciplined another, a reasonable jury could find that these two employees were part of a much larger problem with respect to Miles’s treatment. See McGinest v. GTE Serv. Div., Inc., 89 F.3d 890, 896 (9th Cir. 499). There is evidence in the record that the EEOC’s own investigations did not lead to the termination of the two employees and that, despite the terminations, the employee’s complaints continued.

Whether a federal court, sitting in diversity, has jurisdiction over a claim based on that right, we determine. The answer is no. Rather, the proper inquiry in such a case is whether the complaint stated a claim upon which relief could be granted. See also Id. at 1315, 1317, 1320. This analysis does not apply to the Article III justiciability issues raised in Aheam. The existence vel non of a cause of action is a factor that the Supreme Court has incorporated into the Article III standing inquiry. See Lujan, 504 U.S. at 560, 112 S.Ct. at 1314. Reinforcing this approach is the Court's unambiguous recognition that the standard for evaluating a party's standing to litigate a cause of action will vary according to the particular common-law, statutory, or constitutional claim asserted. See International Primate Products, Inc. v. Washington, 500 U.S. 482, 91 S. Ct. 2132, 2136-37 (1991) (holding). The appellees cite a legion of cases to support their position.

DISCUSSION I. Since there is no legal basis for usurping and encroaching on the district court’s broad equitable powers in this case, I would affirm the decision of the district court. This standard of review is unsupported by case law. See, e.g., Carter v. RMH Teleservices, Inc., 205 F.3d 214, 218 n. 4 (unpublished case 5 Cir.2006) (holding). Since this Court reviews a district court’s grant of summary judgment de novo, a panel must find that the district court abused its discretion in granting summary judgment.

To be attributed to a charging body selected on the basis of race, it cannot be deemed to cure the taint affecting the evidence and is not amenable to harmless error review. Once having found discrimination in the selection of a grand jury, we simply cannot know that the need to indict would have been assessed in the same way by a properly constituted grand jury. The overriding imperative to eliminate this systemic flaw in the charging process, as well as the difficulty of assessing its effect on any given defendant, requires our continued adherence to a rule of mandatory reversal. Defendant argues that “it is inconsistent with Booker to require a sentence which constitutes a substantial variance from the guidelines to be justified by extraordinary circumstances, or to presume that a sentence within the guidelines is reasonable” (Court File No. 64, p. 3). This is not the law in the Sixth Circuit. Substantial variances require extraordinary circumstances. If the court wished to impose a sentence substantially below the guidelines, it must “offer a compelling justification based on the relevant 3553(a) factors that is in proportion to the extent of the variance.” United States v. Borho, 485 F.3d 904, 912 (6th Cir.2007). The compelling justification cannot be based on factors already taken into account by the guidelines. It is not inconsistent with Booker to involve such a consideration (see HOLDING).

Id. The previous kidnapping in this case was clearly not the same fact as the first, in the sense of the traditional purpose of similar fact evidence. But public policy forbids such inquiries. To admit of it would encourage the tampering with jurors after their discharge, would afford a means to corrupt litigants of destroying the effect of a verdict contrary to their interests, and would weaken the public regard for this ancient method of ascertaining the truth of disputed allegations of fact. Absent prejudice and a miscarriage of justice, absent cause and prejudice, a federal habeas court cannot review constitutional claims where a state court has declined to consider their merits on the basis of an adequate and independent state-court rule. Stat.  15A-1419(a)(3), which provides that a claim is “asserted” when the petitioner could have raised it in a previous appeal, but failed to do so.
