There is a conflict between the circuits on the issue of whether the conditions of Karam's release—requiring that she obtain the court's permission before leaving the state and appear before it—amounted to a seizure under the Fourth Amendment. We conclude that they did not. Some courts have held that a seizure occurs only when there is an actual detention. Other circuits have held that some pre-trial restrictions may qualify as a seizure. Riley v. Dotson, 115 F.3d 1159, 1164 (11th Cir. 1997) (rejecting the concept of a seizure occurring during pretrial release); Wilkins v. May, 872 F.2d 190, 194-95 (7th Cir. 1989) (same). See Gallo v. City of Philadelphia, 161 F.3d 217, 219- 320 (3d Cir. 1997) (holding that some restrictions on bail may amount to a seizure); see also see also see: Gallo v. City of Philadelphia, 161 F.3d 856, 861-62 (5th Cir. 1999) (holding that some restrictions on bail may amount to a seizure); Gallo v. Townsend, 169 F.3d 348, 351-59 (11th Cir. 1999)

Between the years 2000 and 2008, the price of a kilogram of heroin appears to have ranged from $60,000 to around $100,000. We assume that the district judges in this circuit, who handle a large number of wholesale drug cases each year, are familiar with these prices and do not require any further evidence of the fact, unless challenged. See United States v. Aina-Marshall, 336 F.3d 167, 169 (2d Cir. 2003); see also United States v. Azubike, 564 F.3d 59, 61 (1st Cir. 2009). In short, since Nino admitted trafficking in a quantity of heroin with a wholesale value of at least six figures, this admission by itself provided a sufficient factual basis for a preponderance of the evidence finding that the proceeds realized by the conspiracy were at least $100,000. This court now turns to Morganti’s breach of contract claims. A contractor’s failure to perform may be excused, and a termination for default converted to a termination for the convenience of the government, if the contractor can establish that the government materially breached the contract. The resolution of these claims should await the resolution of all of Morganti’s payment claims. However, not every departure from the literal terms of a contract is sufficient to constitute a material breach. Stone Forest Indus., v. United States, 849 F.2d 1441, 1445 (Fed. Cir.1988). Cir.1992); Consumers Oil Co., ASBCA No. 24172, 86-1 BCA  18,647, at 93,713, 1985 WL 17314 (Fed. Cir.1988) (holding). The Federal Circuit has held that the ultimate question of whether a breach is material is a question of fact.

The defendant argues that the trial court did not err in excluding the testimony of Dr. Frost. The date of the alleged injury was in 2003. I agree. In Purvis, we held that an expert's testimony was properly excluded when his only knowledge of the locality was four years after the alleged injury. Id. at 480-81, 624 S.E.2d at 385. The fact that the plaintiff's expert relied on internet research is not a sufficient ground to exclude an expert's testimony. Thus, I would affirm the trial court's ruling on that ground. See Coffman v. Roberson, 153 N.C. App. 618, 624-25, 571 S.E.2d 255, 259-61 (2002); see also Durham v. Dillard, 718 N.C. at 719-320, 732 S.E.2d at 74.

Professor Arthur Larson, in his article “Application of Substantial Evidence to Utah Courts,” states that “[a] court of law has not been authorized to make a factual determination about the facts of the case until it has gathered the evidence and weighed the arguments.”

Brown and its progeny therefore imply that sufficient evidence existed for the question of the driver's dominion and control to be submitted to the jury. But this concern is generally not implicated. For example, the State may fail to present evidence inconsistent with a reasonable hypothesis of innocence that a passenger had exclusive dominion and control over the contraband. This amendment broadens the claim as follows: The amendment therefore moves the angling function from a micro level (i.e., provided by the fiber-optic connection) to a macro level, wherein the angling function can presumably be performed by the angling or reconfiguring of the front panel, the cabinet and/or the distribution frame. The Financing Agreement is a contract in which Northwest, as a lender, agrees to loan money to Trace for the construction of Channel 45. The Financing Agreement expressly states that as a condition precedent to performance, Weiss had to obtain the signatures of his partners on the Pledge Agreement. Considering the language of the Financing Agreement, the court also dismisses Northwest’s counterclaim for breach of contract. The Financing Agreement also expressly states that Weiss had to obtain a duly executed Local Marketing Agreement. These requirements are clearly described in terms of conditions and not in terms of promises. See Merritt Hill v. An early case, nearly a contemporary of New York Times, opined that statements made with a “high degree of awareness of their probable falsity” may subject the speaker to civil damages. Garrison, 379 U.S. at 74, 85 S.Ct. at 216, 13 L.Ed.2d at 133. The negative implication of this, of course, is that a court may not award damages against one who negligently communicates a falsehood about a public official. See Masson v. New Yorker Magazine, Inc., 501 U.S. 496, 510, 111 S.Ct. 2419, 2429, 115 L.Ed.2d 447, 468 (Dennis J., dissenting); see also Harte-Hanks Commc’ns, 491 U.S. at 689, 109 S.Ct. 2690, 105 L.Ed.2d at 589 (explaining that establishing liability under New York Times “requires more than a departure from reasonably prudent conduct”). The Supreme Court has explained its view of the situation in several ways, a factual one and a legal one.

Upon learning of this omission, the Developers lodged a protest with the Authority, pointing to the language of the Agreements as affirmatively negating the trial court's subject-matter jurisdiction by showing that the Developers had consented to any alleged taking by the Authority. Accordingly, we must conclude that the actions alleged in the Developers' petition affirmatively negate the trial court's subject-matter jurisdiction by showing that the Developers had consented to any alleged taking by the Authority. See Little-Tex Insulation Co., 39 S.W.3d at 598-99; Steele Co., 236 S.W.2d at 869; Hightower, 134 S.W.2d at 407. -(Holding). W.3d 747, 757-58 (Tex.App.-Houston [14th Dist.] 2004, no pet.) [109]

Although Wilder did not testify pursuant to a plea agreement, the Court finds that the prosecutor’s repeated references to the “minimal” benefit afforded Wilder for his testimony were improper. The Court further finds that these statements tended to mislead the jury, prejudiced petitioner by hampering his ability to fully explore the motives of Wilder for testifying, and were deliberately placed before the jury by the prosecutor. In the context of the relative weakness of the prosecution’s case, which largely rested on Wilder’s testimony and the testimony of admitted drug dealers, the misconduct of the prosecutor rendered the trial fundamentally unfair. See Scott v. Foltz, 612 F. Supp. 50, 58 (E.D.Mich.1985) (Cohn, J.). The Court finds that the state court’s failure to strike the jurors’ “primary basis for their verdicts” (holding that they were “prejudiced”) was a prejudicial error of the first order.

For all these reasons, the Court agrees with the defendant that Mr. Hoover's "old man" comments do not rise to the level of actionable discrimination under the present circumstances. Even viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, the evidence does not demonstrate that Mr. Hoover was a decisionmaker who made deliberate statements showing discriminatory animus. Mr. Hoover left the company on May 5, 2010, three months before the August interviews for the ICS position and had no part in the ICS hiring decision. Random remarks uttered in an ambivalent manner, and not tied directly to the plaintiff's nonselection for the ICS position, do not amount to a claim of discrimination. See Godwin v. Hunt-Wesson, Inc., 150 F.3d 1217, 1221 (9th Cir. 1998), Merrick v. Farmers Ins. Group, 892 F.2d 1434, 1438-39 (9th Cir. 1989); see also Nesbit v. Pepsico, Inc., 994 F.2d 347, 348 (D. Ariz., 1997).

(D) holding that a remark by a decisionmaker made two years before termination was too remote in time to support a finding of pretext for intentional discrimination
(E) holding managers discriminatory remark indicative of age bias where buttressed by other evidence of discrimination and thus remark was not an isolated comment

7. RM Kids further contends that the trial court erred in granting Old Republic’s motion for a directed verdict on its claim for prejudgment interest under OCGA  7–4–15. RM Kids argues that whether the damages were liquidated was an issue for the jury. We disagree. Importantly, a demand is liquidated under the statute. OCGA 7–4–15 provides in pertinent part: “All liquidated demands, where by agreement or otherwise the sum to be paid is fixed or certain, bear interest from the time the party shall become liable and bound to pay them; if payable on demand, they shall bear interest from the time of the demand.” Under this statute, “prejudgment interest, which flows automatically from a liquidated demand, is to be awarded on a judgment for a liquidated amount.” This statute applies to damages. OCGA 7–4–15.

This doctrine was extended to automobiles in the case of the S. C. Oil Company v. Anderson, 80 Fla. 441, 86 So. 629, 1920. In that case, the Court stated: "The principles of the common law do not permit the owner of an instrument which, although not inherently dangerous, is peculiarly dangerous in its use, to authorize another person to use that instrument on the public highway, without imposing upon such owner liability for the negligent use of the instrument. " The liability is due to the obligation of the owner to have the vehicle, which is not inherently dangerous per se, but peculiarly dangerous in its use, properly operated, when by his authority it is on the public highway. The same rule was applied in Harding v. Allen-Laux, Inc., 559 So. 2d 107, 109 (Fla. 5th. DCA., 1994).

THE COURT also expressed its concern about imposing asymmetric liability costs on private operators as compared to government operators. The Court in the case of Malesko, 534 U.S. at 72, 122 S. Ct. 515, expressed its concern about imposing asymmetric costs on private operators in relation to government operators. Unfortunately, under the current Bivens regime, such asymmetries may remain irrespective of whether we recognize or deny a Bivens cause of action here. Unlike officers employed in public prisons, the GEO employees may not be entitled to qualified immunity, and as a result prisoners asserting claims against them may be able to recover more often than prisoners in government-run prisons. We are equally concerned about issuing a decision that will lead to disparate rights and remedies between inmates in private and public prisons. Compare Richardson, 521 U.S. at 401, 117 S. Ct. 2100 (RENEWED) with Butz v. Economou, 438 U.S. 478, 501, 98 S. Ct. 1461, and this opinion.

In the Indentures, an “Event of Default” occurs when the Issuer materially breaches its obligations, is notified of such breach by the Trustee or by a certain percentage of investors, and fails to cure such material breach within thirty days. (Sample Indenture, Appendix A, p. 87.) Citibank argues that plaintiffs fail to plead that any Issuer in fact received notice of a default. (Def.’s Mem. 28-29.) In re Bankers Trust Co., 450 F.3d at 129 (internal quotation marks and alteration omitted). But Citibank may not excuse its failure to perform the additional duties required after an “Event of Default” by pointing to its own failure to give notice. It may not “take advantage of its own wrong.” In re Bankers Trust Co., 450 F.3d at 130 (holding). This principle holds true even if Citibank in fact failed to give notice to the Issuers.

Therefore, Gallagher must show that it and the Diocese modified their contract to discharge Gallagher from the warranty. Under Louisiana law, contracts may be modified only by mutual consent of the parties to the contract. See Williams Eng’g, Inc. v. Goodyear, 480 So.2d 772, 778 (La.App. 2 Cir.1985), aff’d, 496 So.2d 1012 (La. 1986). To constitute a valid modification, an agreement must be clearly defined and the party sought to be held to the modification must in fact have agreed to and authorized the modification. See Cardos v. Cristadoro, 228 La. 975, 84 So.2d 606, 610 (La.1954) (holding); see also Wise v. Lapworth, 614 So.2d 728, 731 (La.App. 4 Cir.1992), aff’d, 614 So.2d at 732–33.)

After hearing the arguments, the trial court orally announced that it would deny the motion. The trial court did not sign a written order; hence the motion was overruled by operation of law. See Tex.R.Civ.P.. 329b(c). We review a trial court’s ruling on a motion for a new trial for abuse of discretion. When moving for a new trial to set aside a default judgment for failure to appear for trial, a defendant must (1) prove that his failure to appear was not intentional or the result of conscious indifference but was due to a mistake or accident, (2) set forth a meritorious defense, and (3) show that a new trial would be to the injured party’s advantage. Div. v. Evans, 889 S.W.2d 266, 268 (Tex.1994). Next, the appellant argues that the judgment should be set aside, and we must follow the ruling in Moss v. Gregor, 186 S.W.3d 571, 574 (Tex.2006) (per curiam).

However, there is no reason to make such a comprehensive statement here. We find that under the traditional equitable mootness analysis, this case is not moot. We begin with some standard qualifiers to equitable mootness. “Substantial consummation of a reorganization plan is a momentous event, but it does not necessarily make it impossible or inequitable for an appellate court to grant effective relief.” In re Manges, 29 F.3d at 1042–43 (internal quotation marks and citation omitted). Moreover, “equitable mootness need not foreclose an appeal from aspects of a Chapter 11 plan confirmation that solely concern professional compensation and releases.” In re Hilal, 534 F.3d at 501. No matter what else may be equitably moot, the instant case is not.

Angus Chem. Co. v. IMC Fertilizers, Inc., 939 S.W.2d 138 (Tx., 1997). This result places Texas among the majority of other jurisdictions that have considered the question. In other words, State Farm's duty is to pay its insured; third parties can only obtain a recovery under the policy if their rights derive from the rights of Fullerton to obtain them. In other words, although the courts of this State have not yet decided whether the plaintiffs in the tort claim are in privity with the insured who pleads guilty to murder, we hold that, under the Texas law, the Buckners are in privity with Fullerton because of the derivative nature of their recovery under the policy. The Buckners' recovery under the policy derives from the antecedent liability of State Farm to indemnify its insured for the tort of murder. See, e.g., Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co. v. Jones, 220 Conn. 285, 596 A.2d 414, 421, 425, 59 (holding); Tradewind Ins. Co. v. Taylor, 183 So. 2d 166, 174 (Tenn., 1997). See also Watkins v. Atl-Atl, 848 So. 2d 477, 482 (La. 1997).

Eddie’s argument is untenable for two reasons. First, the extent of Diana’s community interest is governed by the fraction formula established in Taggart v. Taggart, 552 S.W.2d 422 (Tex.1977), whereas the value of her interest is governed by the Berry formula. Under the Taggart formula, the extent of the non-member spouse’s community interest in retirement benefits is calculated by dividing the number of months married under the plan by the total number of months employed at retirement. In Berry, however, the court, while reserving the right to modify the formula, significantly altered it. See Shanks v. Treadway, 110 S.W.3d 444, 446 n.3 (Tex.2003) (holding); Wilson v. Uzzel, 953 S.W.2d 384, 390 (Tex.

The court did not address these questions left open by Gardner, because of the scope of the waiver that a State can effect by filing a proof of claim. It remains open in Gardner whether such a filing waives immunity as to all claims against the State, or whether it waives immunity only as to some claims and not to others, or whether it merely prevents the State from asserting its immunity in response to objections raised against its claim (as in the present case). The main purpose of the word "willfully" is therefore to serve as a legislative hint of self-restraint for the administrator. See  204 (a) (2) (B) ct. id. See also State v. Dumke, 498 S.W.2d 100, 103 (TX 91 ct. app. 1990) (Ct.App.1969) (Holding).

When determining whether an insurer has breached its duty to defend, the relevant consideration is not the raw chronology of the delay in filing the declaratory judgment action, but whether the insurer waited until trial or settlement was imminent. Westchester Fire Insurance Co. v. Heileman Brewing Co., 321 Ill. App. 3d 622, 634, 747 N.E.2d 955, 965 (2000). In the instant case, Aetna breached its duty to defend at least some of the underlying suits because it did not bring the declaratory judgment action until 11 months after the plaintiffs had released Rourke for the full amount of the settlements in those cases. In those cases in which the trial court determines that Aetna did not breach its duty to defend, Aetna should be permitted to raise coverage defenses. See e.g., EMPLOYERS INSU., 186 Ill. 2d 151, 151-52, 708 N.E.2d at 1135. The court should then determine whether any defense is meritorious and decide accordingly.
Choices:
(A) holding that duty to defend ends when it is apparent there is no potential for coverage
(B) recognizing that policy determines duty
(C) holding that insurer had a continuing duty to defend
(D) holding that an insurer can normally dispute coverage even after a court determines there is a duty to defend
(E) holding where there is no duty to defend there is no duty to indemnify

The trial court decided that the sale value should be based on the fair market value at the time of marriage and not on the original purchase price. We agree. The trial court erred in this respect. On the other hand, the trial court did not err in using the purchase price to calculate a rate of return on the Alice property, because that property was acquired after the parties were married. (Id., p. 16). Dorbin does not state how the community's interest in the increased value of a separate asset should be calculated when the asset is alienated during marriage and another asset is bought in its place, or even whether it should be calculated at all on alienated property. This Court has recognized in dicta, however, that it may be calculated at each alienation. See White v. White, 105 N.M. 600, 605, 734 P.2d 1283, 1289 (Ct. App.1987) (citing Dorbin, 105 N.M. at 263, 731 P.2d at 965).

(D) holding that there was sufficient probable cause to search a defendants residence after evidence of drug dealing was found in his car during a traffic stop that was conducted when the defendant was coming from his residence and noting that under such circumstances a practical commonsense conclusion could be made that the drugs and money had been at the defendants residence a short time before the stop
(E) holding that tjhere is a strong legal presumption that all property acquired during marriage is community property

CONSISTENT WITH THE LAW, A CAUSE OF ACTION IS CONTINUED AFTER THE DEATH OF THE PERSON TO WHOM IT BELONGS ... and in tort actions based on personal injuries, the damages recoverable after the death of the person to whom the action accrued shall be limited to loss of earnings and expenses sustained or incurred prior to death and shall not include damages for pain, suffering, disfigurement, or for profits and earnings after the date of death. This provision is not inconsistent with the ADA, which does not address the availability of damages after the death of the injured person. It is also not necessarily inconsistent with the principles underlying the ADA, such as deterrence and victim compensation. (Robertson, 436 U.S. at 590-91, 98 S. Ct. at 1996 (HOLDING)). Accordingly, I find and conclude that the PLF statute is constitutional.

Malmstrom v. St. Vrain County, 236 Mont. 412, 418, 771 P.2d 97, 101 (1989)  The district court may rule on a motion for summary judgment without a hearing. Chapman v. Maxwell, 2014 MT 35,  11, 374 Mont. 12, 322 P.3d 1029 (citing SVKV, L.L.C. v. Townsend, 200 Mont. 402, 79 P.3d 1035, 1042 (Mont. 2002)). We have held that “there may be occasions where the movant is so clearly entitled to a judgment as a matter of law that the district court may dispense with the need for a hearing.” Richards v. County, 334 Mont. 395, 148 P.3d 584  37 (Mont. 2006). In certain circumstances, the district court may dispense with a hearing. We will not find reversible error for failing to hold a hearing on a summary judgment motion if the hearing would not raise any issue of material fact. Richards,  25-26. See also Dollar Plus,  39 (holding that the district court could properly enter summary judgment without a hearing when the hearing would not have created a factual issue).

“Each incident of stalking must be proven by competent, substantial evidence to support an injunction against stalking.” Touhey v. Seda, 133 So.3d 1203, 1204 (Fla. 2d DCA 2014). See Roach v. Brower, 180 So.3d 1142, 1144 (Fla. 2d DCA 2015). Courts “apply the reasonable person standard, not a subjective standard, to determine whether an incident causes substantial emotional distress.” Id., at 1204 (internal quotation marks omitted). Here, Ms. Schack testified that appellant banged on her door and left her a letter and a check. Using the reasonable person standard, it is difficult to see how this behavior would rise to the level of causing “substantial emotional distress.” See Leach v. Kersey, 162 So.3d 1104, 1106-07 (Fla. 2d DCA 2015) (holding that “a reasonable person would have found this to be sufficiently extreme to cause substantial emotional distress.”). Furthermore, even viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Ms. Schack, we do not believe that it satisfies the objective standard of “substantial emotional distress.

The prosecutor only made two statements which were potentially serious breaches of the Caldwell principle. The first statement was made by the prosecutor who, in addressing the jury, stated that they could not recommend the death penalty “unless they first decided that an aggravating factor exists.” J.A. Bowling alleges that the jury’s responsibility for the death penalty was unconstitutionally lessened by the use of the word “recommend.” We have held, however, that this statement does not misstate local law, because the statutes themselves use the word “recommend.” See Ky. Rev. Code Ann.  532.025(l)(b); see also Kordenbrock v. Scroggy, 919 F.2d 1091, 1101 (6th Cir. 1990, en banc) (holding). Therefore, this statement was not made in violation of the Caldwell principle.

We see that the appellant does not present its own cross-elasticity analysis to show that the district court’s approach is wrong. Rather, it merely points out that the court’s definition is inadequately supported and therefore cannot stand. But this was an issue for Buccaneer to resolve in the first instance, and the district court’s independent excursion into market definition does not absolve Buccaneer of this burden. And the cases on which Buccaneer relies, in which this court has reversed trial courts’ market definitions as inadequately supported by interchangeability and cross-elasticity principles, do not suggest otherwise: see Telecor, 305 F.3d at 1131-32; Westman Communication Co. v. Hobart Int’l, Inc., 796 F.2d 1216, 1221 (C.A.10 1989); Campfield, 532 F.3d at 1118. In fact, Telecor squarely cuts against Buccaneer’s position: see 305 F.3d at 1131-32 (holding that this court’s conclusion in a case with similar facts was “unsound”). Finally, even if we could infer from the language in the case law that market definitions should be avoided, we could not do so.

Most obvious example: when a suspect flees from the police. See Wardlow, 528 U.S. at 121, 120 S.Ct. 673; Hodari D., 499 U.S. at 626, 111 S.Ct. 591. . . . Brower v. County of Inyo, 489 U.S. 593, 596–97, 109 S.Ct. 1378, 103 L.Ed.2d 627, overruled by Keating, 533 F.3d 1547, 1094, 1095. But flight is not required when the suspect otherwise takes action to evade or threaten police officers. We found no flight in the case of Waterman v. United States, 569 F.3d 145, where the suspect, responding to a police officer's command to show his hands, reached to his waistband and, after stepping through a door, disappeared from the officers' presence. Other courts have found no submission where a suspect who is already in motion refuses to stop when an officer approaches. See United States v. Freeman, 735 F.3d 92, 95–97 (2d Cir.2013) (holding); see also United States v. Johnson, 620 F.3d 685, 691–92 (9th Cir.2010) (same).

Because the jury was permitted to convict Mr. Williams despite the lack of sufficient evidence, the result of the trial was fundamentally unfair. Garner v. State, 550 N.E.2d 1309, 1312 (Ind. Ct. App. 1990). In the instant case, the crux of Mr. Williams’s claim of ineffective assistance is the same as his claim of fundamental error—that his convictions lacked sufficient evidentiary support. Generally, allegations of errors not raised on direct appeal are considered waived for purposes of post-conviction relief. Green v. State, 525 N.E.2d 1260, 1261 (Ind. Ct. App. 1988). However, conviction without sufficient evidence constitutes fundamental error, and fundamental error may be raised in a post-conviction proceeding, consistent with the applicable rules of procedure. Id. See also Smith v. State, 559 N.E.2d 888, 890 (Ind. Ct. App. 1991). We therefore examine the merits of Mr. Williams’s fundamental error claim.

(B) holding that postconviction proceeding is a civil suit
(C) recognizing that rule 32 is a postconviction remedy
(D) holding that claims not raised in a timely postconviction motion are waived
(E) holding that insufficiency of evidence not cognizable in postconviction claim

“A certificate of the person authorized to administer oaths, and officially certified to by the officer under his seal of office.” Tex. Gov’t Code  312.011(1). This definition contains the “statutory requirements” for an affidavit. Ford Motor Co. v. Leggat, 904 S. W. 2d 643, 645 (Tex. 1995). When an affidavit meets the statutory requirements, it may be presented as summary judgment evidence, if it complies with Texas Rule of Civil Procedure 56. See Tex. R. Civ. P. 166a(f); Life Ins. Co. of Am. v. Hopkins, 671 S. W. 2d 92, 94 ( ). When a written statement does not meet this basic definition, however, it is “no affidavit at all.” Hardy v. Beaty, 84 Tex. 562, 19 S. W. 2d 712 ( ). See also Anderson v. Cochran, 93 Tex. 583, 57 S. W. 2d 778, 779 ( ).

The decision does not cite the mere use of the information as sufficient to sustain a finding of trade secret status or even as a factor relevant to the inquiry. Moreover, the mere use of the information is not even cited as a factor relevant to the determination of the trade secret status. Then, too, the Court observed that a plaintiff “has the burden of proving the existence of a trade secret, and there is no presumption in its favor.” See 625 P.2d at 696. Midgley did testify that the information took “years” to develop. However, this generality fails to demonstrate a genuine issue of material fact for two reasons. First, Midgley did not substantiate his statement that it took years to develop the information by any evidence of how many years it took. In his deposition Midgley testified that he did not know how many years it took to develop the information. Id. at 700 (holding).

Of the decisions that Velez-Alderete cites, none of them supports his view that arson requires a separate requirement of possible harm to a person. To the contrary, see United States v. Sedima, 324 F.3d 362, 369–70 (11th Cir.2003) (Sedima).

“[I]t is well established that property deemed exempt from the bankruptcy estate belongs to the debtor and is withdrawn from the estate and hence from the creditors for the benefit of the debtor.” See also Smith v. Kennedy, In re Smith, 235 F.3d 472, 478 (D.C. Cir. 2000) (“It is widely accepted that property deemed exempt from the bankruptcy estate belongs to the debtor.”) As the Second Circuit has stated, “[t]o put it quite simply, property that has been exempted belongs to the debtor.” Bell v. Bell, In re Bell, 225 F.3d 203, 216 (2d Cir. 2000). This principle is consistent with the text of the Bankruptcy Code, which defines exempt property as property that, unlike all other property of the debtor, does not belong to the bankruptcy estate. See 11 U.S.C.  101. * * * We adopt this view of the common law because of the clear and unambiguous language of Exemptions Acts. See also S. Rep. No. 95-989, at 52, 53–54, reprinted in 1978 U.S.C.C.A.N. 5787, 5838 (holding). Similarly, the homestead exemptions available to the debtor in the state of residence apply to the debtor’s residence, which is also the exempt property.”

When the basis of an ineffective assistance claim is the failure of appellate counsel to raise an issue on appeal, “we must look to the merits of the omitted issue.” United States v. Orange, 447 F.3d 792, 797 (10th Cir. 2006) (Orange). “If the omitted issue is without merit, counsel’s failure to raise it does not constitute constitutionally ineffective assistance of counsel.” Cook, 45 F.3d at 393 (quoting United States v. Dixon, 1 F.3d 1080, 1084 n.5 (10th Cir.1993) (internal quotation marks omitted)). Further, if counsel was not ineffective in failing to raise a claim on appeal, a defendant cannot satisfy the cause requirement to excuse his procedural default of the claim. See Challoner, 583 F.3d 748, 749-51 (holding). The district court analyzed and rejected each of Doe’s arguments.

The Wirth petition was rejected by the NHTSA. It was based on research by Leon Robertson, who was an expert for the plaintiffs. Nevertheless, plaintiffs wanted to introduce the memoranda, in which NHTSA staff members expressed opinions that support Robertson's methodology and the theory of the plaintiffs. The district court excluded these memoranda on hearsay grounds. The plaintiffs argue on appeal that these memoranda satisfy federal rule of evidence 803(8), which excludes certain public records from the general rule that hearsay is inadmissible. The rule exempts records, reports, statements, or data compilations in any form of public offices or agencies setting forth (A) the activities of the office or agency, (B) the official policies of the office or agency, ... or (C) the official opinions of the officers or agencies, which are otherwise relevant to the case (Reeves v. Smith, ___ U.S. ___, 117 S. Ct. at 346). The opinions expressed in these memoranda were not the official opinions of the NHTSA staff.

“In each case,” we must “judge the officer’s suspicions,” and decide “whether he had any objective, particularized basis for suspecting a violation of the law.” United States v. Arvizu, 534 U.S. 266, 273, 122 S. Ct. 744, 151 L. Ed. 2d 740 (2002). Agent Wolfe did not act on a “hunch” alone; he observed that Wingfield had an empty cell phone clip on his belt, and then verified that his parole order prohibited him from carrying a cell phone. We find that Wolfe reasonably suspected that Wingfield possessed a cell phone in violation of his parole. Accordingly, the resulting detention and search met constitutional requirements. See Hill, 967 F.2d at 909 (holding). Alternatively stated, we find it reasonable to believe that Wolfe had reasonable suspicion to believe that Wingfield had a cell phone.

The Court may grant summary judgment when “the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.” Fed. R. Civ. P. 56. The task before the Court is to examine the record and determine whether there are triable issues of fact concerning whether the allegedly violative conduct occurred. The Court is not to construe the parties’ allegations as such. See, e.g., Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 323-23 , 106 S. Ct. 2548, 91 L. Ed. 2d 265 (1996); Felty v. Graves-Humphreys Co., 818 F.2d 1126, 1128 (11th Cir.) (holding that a defendant’s allegations were true, and that he was entitled to summary judgment as a matter of law). Nevertheless, in determining whether a genuine issue of material fact exists, the Court must examine the record as a whole.

Steel argued that the type of injury for which it sought an injunction was “not the type of injury that would entitle a plaintiff to compensation if the injury actually occurred.” Id. at 1270. This conclusion is mistaken because it ignores the distinction that was stated above between showing that an antitrust injury has actually occurred in the past and showing that it might occur in the future. The fact that the arbitrators concluded that B-S Steel failed to meet its evidentiary burden in regard to past violations does not mean, as a matter of law, that it would be impossible for B-S Steel to show a threat of future injury. Indeed, as recognized above, B-S Steel offered different evidence of injury after December 31, 2001. Hayden Co. v. Siemens Medical System, Inc., 879 F.2d 1005, 1022 (2d Cir.1989). While the plaintiff bears the burden of proving that the defendant’s negligence more likely than not caused the injury, this burden does not “logically compel the conclusion that the defendant is precluded from offering evidence of possible explanations other than his ... negligence. Id. (emphasis in original). As the court stated in Haas, probabilities “are provoked by possibilities ... In a logical sense, probabilities may be deduced only from an analysis of all the possibilities.” Id. The defendant’s ability to present alternate causes is of paramount importance in allowing for an adequate defense. See, e.g., Guinn v. AstraZeneca Pharm. LP, 602 F.3d 1245, 1253 (11th Cir.2010) (holding). These principles are in keeping with both the principles of equity and of common sense.

(D) holding misrepresentation must at least be partial cause of plaintiffs injury
(E) holding that the plaintiffs lacked standing to pursue a permanent nuisance action for injury to property because none of the plaintiffs were the owners of the land when the cause of action accrued with the first injury

Because we agree with the rationale in the case of McCloud I, we reject Gulf's attempt to distinguish this case on the above mentioned basis. In Carnes, we applied the going and coming rule, and we declined to adopt the employee's own conveyance rule, in finding that a newspaper deliverer was not acting within the course and scope of her employment when she drove her vehicle home after completing her deliveries for the day. 227 Ariz. 34, 6, 251 P.3d 413. In general, under the going and coming rule, an employer is not liable for the tortious acts of an employee while the employee is going to or returning from the place of employment. Id. (quoting State v. Superior Court (Schraft), 111 Ariz. 130, 132, 524 P.2d 951, 953 (holding)). The employee's own conveyance rule is a more limited exception to the going and coming rule.
Choices:
(A) holding that a defendant who accepts the benefits of control release waives any argument that application of the control release program in the form of the forfeiture of gain time was an ex post violation because control release was enacted after the date of his or her offenses

(C) holding that the right to control the means by which the work is accomplished is clearly the most significant test of the employment relationship and observing that many of the other factors enumerated in the restatement second are merely evidentiary indicia of the right to control
(D) holding that the protest statutes use of the word cumulative means the statute is in addition to the existing right of reimbursement for taxes wrongfully demanded not intended to destroy that legal right
(E) recognizing that a suit by the national government against a state does no violence to the inherent nature of sovereignty

The question of whether an argument is colorable can have no disadvantage, since the Court reviews a CUE motion under the same standard by which it reviews matters on direct appeal. Generally, challenges to final decisions based on CUE fall into two broad categories: “Either the correct facts as they were known at the time were not before the adjudicator, or the statutory or regulatory provisions extant at the time were incorrectly applied.” Russell v. Principi, 3 Vet.App. 187 (op. cit.). The latter of these categories — that the law was incorrectly applied — can and should be raised on direct appeal, where a claimant has a much lower evidentiary burden to satisfy. See King, 26 Vet.App. 310, 313 (en banc) . The former category, however, where the correct facts as they were known at the time were not before the adjudicator, must be raised in a timely CUE motion, and the burden is comparatively higher.
Choices:
(A) holding that cue required a showing that the alleged error in the challenged decision would have manifestly changed the outcome at the time it was made
(B) holding there was not plain error because a different result probably would not have been reached absent the trial courts alleged error
(C) holding that to prove the existence of cue  the claimant must show that an outcomedeterminative error occurred  which means that absent the alleged clear and unmistakable error the benefit sought would have been granted at the outset quoting bustos v west 179 f3d 1378 1381 fedcir1999
(D) holding that where the record is insufficient to show that the alleged error occurred the presumption that the trial court acted without error must prevail
(E) holding that party asserting plain error must show a reasonable probability that but for the error claimed the result of the proceeding would have been different

The second paragraph of the same paragraph expressly makes use of “management’s reasonable discretion” (Exhibit A at 6), and the word “encourages” is a permissive word and not a mandatory word. The D.C. Court of Appeals has found that the use of such permissive language in a personnel manual is, as a matter of law, insufficient to create any kind of contract rights. Perkins v. District of Columbia Governmental Employees Federal Credit Union, 653 A.2d 842, 843 (D.C. 1997) (determining that the language “may” in a personnel manual was insufficient to conclude that the parties intended to create a contract). The cited provisions cannot be considered to be “rationally at odds” with the handbook’s disclaimer of a contract. See Hopkins v. Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, No. 10-900, 2010 WL 5300536, at 4 (D.D.C. 2010) (holding). Therefore, under D.C. law, the alleged contract does not exist.
Choices:
(A) holding similar language to be a valid disclaimer
(B) holding that a standard form disclaimer for negligence of thirdparty tour operators which appeared on plaintiffs cruise ticket was valid as a disclaimer
(C) holding that the language in the lease agreement for computer accounting programs was an effective disclaimer of an implied warranty but for language in a statement of installation conditions which document created a genuine issue of material fact as to disclaimer
(D) holding inconspicuous written disclaimer to be unenforceable absent actual knowledge of the disclaimer
(E) holding that compensation and performance guidelines were not rationally at odds with handbooks disclaimer language

During the search, Dahl found several items in the trunk that he recognized as commonly used in the manufacture of methamphetamine. At the time he found the backpack, he had already found the chemical book on the floor in the passenger compartment where the defendant had been sitting, and he had also found contraband in the defendant’s fanny pack. He then went into the store to arrest the defendant and Johnson. When he found the contraband in the trunk, he contacted the narcotics team to continue the search, because he was concerned about the hazardous nature of methamphetamine production. The facts, taken together, support the inference that the officers subjectively believed that the occupants were involved in the manufacture of methamphetamine. However, of course, probable cause alone is not sufficient to a search.

The defense asked the question about the knowledge of Jeffrey Gibson of the defendant’s past convictions. The defense objected and asked for a mistrial. The accused answered that she had told him about the manslaughter conviction. The district court then gave the jury a curative instruction, in which it instructed them to disregard the reference to the prior conviction. The government properly concedes that the admission of this conviction was an error, as it dates from the year 1974. We must nonetheless determine whether the impermissible reference to the prior conviction was harmless in light of the district court’s curative instruction and the other admissible evidence adduced in support of the defendant’s conviction. Evid. 609(b). While the government’s initial brief claims that the district court’s curative instruction made the prior conviction harmless, we note that the government’s own brief also argues that the error was not harmless. See United States v. LeQuire, 943 F.2d 1554, 1571–72 (11th Cir.1991) (holding, at para. 10).
Choices:
(A) holding prejudicial effect of prosecutors comment not rendered harmless by courts general instruction that the arguments of counsel are not evidence
(B) holding harmless an inadmissible comment as prejudicial effect was removed by district courts curative instruction
(C) recognizing that use of curative or limiting instructions is within the district courts discretion
(D) holding that a district court can cure the effect of an improper prosecutorial comment with a jury instruction
(E) holding that where an objection is sustained and curative instruction given and no further relief such as a mistrial additional curative instruction or striking of the offending comment is requested there is nothing for the appellate court to review

"Six months after the May 1, 1999, investigation, the Board of Immigration Appeals, citing In re O-D-l7 I & N Dec. 1079, 1083, 1998 WL 24904 (BIA 1998), found that this forgery indicated a lack of credibility with regard to Ebid's testimony in general and, in particular, to his testimony about the May 1999 incident. " Ebid claims that the asylum officer erred in making an adverse credibility determination based on the submission of one forged document, which he explained as the result of his friend's advice that he needed corroboration and could not get one from his doctor in Egypt. We disagree. An asylum applicant's knowing use of a fraudulent document that goes to the heart of his or her asylum claim, without sufficient explanation, can be substantial evidence to support an asylum officer's decision. See In re O-D-, l7 I & N Dec. at 1083 (holding as much); accord Borovikova v. Department of Justice, 92 F.3d 94, 95-96 (E.D. Pa. 1993) (similarly holding). "

(D) holding that an asylum applicants submission of false documents without an adequate explanation supported adverse credibility findings
(E) holding that an adverse credibility determination is sufficient to deny asylum
